DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-26—2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Meetings to be open to public, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1; exemptions from open meeting requirements, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3; due notice requirements for other than regular meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d); requirement to prescribe the time, place and dates of regular meetings of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). 

Sec. 2-41. - Officers. 
(a)  Chairman. The chairman of the board of commissioners is responsible for the orderly conduct of the meeting. In order to fulfill this duty, the chairman must enforce the rules of procedure that are adopted by the board of commissioners. The chairman shall be impartial and conduct the meetings in a fair manner. The chairman may not introduce motions or second a motion except that the chairman may introduce or second a motion to go into executive session as authorized by section 2-52. The chairman shall not vote except to break a tie. 
(b)  Vice chairperson. The vice chairperson selection process beginning January 1, 2015 and continuing thereafter: 
(1)  Beginning January 1, 2015, the selection of the vice chairperson shall be by sequential rotation to begin with the district one commissioner as the 2015 vice chairperson. 
(2)  Each successive year thereafter the vice chairperson position shall automatically be filled by the commissioner holding the seat of the next numerical district in ascending order. However, if for any reason the commission district member, who would be the board vice chairperson as determined by the sequential rotation outlined above, cannot serve then the vice chairperson position shall automatically be filled by the commissioner holding the seat of the next numerical district in ascending order and said replacement will serve the remainder of the unfulfilled term plus one upcoming full term. Furthermore, at no time will any commissioner serve more than a one year term, unless said commissioner has filled an unexpired term as described above, as vice chairperson. Once the commissioner holding the seat of the district with the highest numerical value has served, the rotation shall begin again with district one and rotate as provided herein. 
(3)  Term. Beginning January 1, 2015, the term for the position of vice chairperson shall be one year. 
(c)  Parliamentarian. The county attorney shall serve as the parliamentarian for board meetings. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, §§ 1-05, 1-06, 1-12, 11-13-95; Res. No. 2015-01, §§ 1, 2, 2-12-15) 
Sec. 2-42. - Decorum. 
(a)  All commissioners shall conduct themselves in a professional and respectful manner. All remarks shall be directed to the chairman and not to individual commissioners, staff or citizens in attendance. Personal remarks are inappropriate. A commissioner is not allowed to speak at a meeting until he has been recognized by the chairman. All comments made by a commissioner shall address the motion that is being discussed. 
(b)  The chairman shall enforce these rules of decorum. If a commissioner believes that a rule has been broken, he may raise a point of order. A second is not required. The chairman can rule on the question or he can allow the board to debate the issue and decide the issue by majority vote of those present and voting. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-10, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-43. - Committees. 
The chairman may create committees of members of the board to study any issue before the board. Any such committees may make recommendations to the board of commissioners, but no committee shall be empowered to make any final decision on any matter before it for consideration. In addition to board members, committees may include other county officials, staff or citizens at large. Whenever a committee is created, its duties, any limitations of the scope of its duties, and the times, places and periods of time for which the committee may operate shall be determined by the chairman. The chairman shall serve as an ex officio member of all committees. All committee meetings shall be held in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-18, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-44. - Quorum. 
A quorum must be present for conducting meetings of the board. A quorum is a majority of all of the members of the board then in office. It is the duty of the chairman to enforce this rule. Any commissioner may raise a point of order directed to the chairman if he believes that a quorum is not present. If, during the course of a meeting, a commissioner leaves and a quorum no longer exists, the meeting cannot continue. If a quorum is not attained within 30 minutes, the meeting will be rescheduled by the chairman with the approval of the commissioners present. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-02, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-45. - Voting; majority; abstentions. 
(a)  Passage of a motion shall require four affirmative votes of the board at a meeting at which a quorum is present. In the event of a tie vote, the chairman shall vote to break the tie. If for any reason, less than six members of the board vote on any issue, the chairman shall also vote on said issue. 
(b)  In the case of a roll-call vote, the name of each person voting for or against a proposal shall be recorded in the minutes, and in all other cases it shall be presumed that the action taken was approved by each person in attendance unless the minutes reflect the name of the persons voting against the proposal or abstaining. 
(c)  A commissioner shall vote on all motions unless he has a conflict of interest which would prevent him from making a decision in a fair and legal manner. If a conflict of interest does exist, the commissioner shall explain for the record his decision to abstain on any vote. Abstentions shall not be considered a vote of any nature, affirmative, negative or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, §§ 1-03, 1-04, 11-13-95; Res. No. 2008-42, 3-10-08) 
Sec. 2-46. - Visual and sound recordings. 
Visual, sound and visual and sound recordings shall be permitted for all public meetings. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-19, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-47. - Types of meetings. 
(a)  Open meetings. All meetings of the board of commissioners shall be held in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. The public shall at all times be afforded access to all meetings other than executive sessions. 
(b)  Regular meetings. Meetings of the board of commissioners shall be held at 7:30 p.m. on the second Monday of each month. Regular work sessions of the board shall be held at 7:30 p.m. on the Tuesday immediately preceding the second Monday of each month. All meetings shall be held in the county administrative building unless circumstances dictate a change or a change is directed by majority vote of the board. Should the regular meeting be held at a location other than the county administrative building, notice shall be given as provided for a special meeting or rescheduled regular meeting. A notice containing the foregoing information shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place available to the general public at the regular meeting place of the board. 
(c)  Special meetings and rescheduled regular meetings. A regular meeting may be canceled, rescheduled or moved to a new location within the county by the chairman for any reason. Other special meetings may be scheduled by the chairman or at the request of three commissioners to the chairman. Whenever a rescheduled regular meeting or any other special meeting is to be held at a time or place other than the regularly scheduled time or place, written notice of the change shall be posted for at least 24 hours at the place of the regular meetings. In addition, written or oral notice shall be given by the clerk at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting to either the legal organ of the county or a newspaper having a general circulation at least equal to that of the legal organ and to each member of the county governing authority. 
(d)  Emergency meetings. When emergency circumstances occur, the board may hold a meeting with less than 24 hours' notice to the public. When such meetings are to be held, the clerk shall provide notice to the legal organ of the county or a newspaper with a general circulation at least equal to that of the legal organ and to each member of the county governing authority as soon as possible. The notice shall include the subjects expected to be considered at the meeting. In addition, the minutes shall reflect the reason for the emergency meeting and the nature of the notice given to the media. 
(e)  Executive sessions. Executive sessions of the board may be held for the purpose of conducted business excepted from public access requirements as authorized by O.C.G.A. §§ 50-14-2 and 50-14-3. Where a meeting of the board is devoted in part to matters within the authorized exceptions to public access requirements, any portion of the meeting not subject to any such exceptions shall be open to the public. No executive session shall be held except pursuant to a majority affirmative vote of the board of commissioners taken in a public meeting. The minutes of the public meeting shall reflect the names of the commissioners present, those voting for the executive session and the specific reasons for the executive session. Minutes of the executive session may be maintained by the clerk of the board of commissioners at the direction of the chairman. Any such minutes shall be maintained in a confidential file and shall not be subject to disclosure, except that disclosures of such portions of minutes identifying real estate to be acquired by the board may only be delayed until such time as the acquisition of the real estate has been completed, terminated or abandoned or court proceedings have been initiated. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, §§ 1-01, 1-13—1-16, 11-13-95; Ord. of 4-14-97, § 1) 
Sec. 2-48. - Public participation. 
(a)  Generally. Public participation in meetings of the board of commissioners shall be permitted in accordance with the provisions of this section. All remarks by the public shall be directed to the chairman and not to individual commissioners, staff or citizens in attendance. 
(b)  Public comments. The final agenda item of each regular meeting shall be reserved for comments from the public, if any. All members of the public who wish to address the board must submit their name and the specific topic of their comments to the county administrator at least two business days before the board meeting. These individuals will be allotted five minutes to make their comments, and their comments must be limited to their chosen topic. These limits may be waived by a majority vote of the board. 
(c)  Decorum. Members of the public shall not make inappropriate or offensive comments at a board meeting and are expected to comply with the rules of decorum that are established for commissioners. Individuals who violate any rules of the board may be ruled out of order by the chairperson or on a point of order made by a commissioner. A majority vote of the board will rule on the point of order. An individual who violates the rules of decorum may be removed from the meeting at the direction of the chairperson. 
(d)  Public hearings. The board may schedule public hearings for the purpose of soliciting public comment on any subject of interest to the board. Hearings may be held immediately prior to or following a meeting of the board or at such other places and times as the board may determine. All comments at a public hearing shall address the subject of the hearing. Comments on any subject other than that of the public hearing shall be ruled out of order. No official action shall be taken at any such public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-11, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-49. - Order of business. 
All regular board meetings should follow an established order of business. The order is as follows: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Invocation. 
(3)  Minutes. 
(4)  Zoning hearings and decisions. 
(5)  Invited guests. 
(6)  Reports from committees and departments. 
(7)  Old business. 
(8)  New business. 
(9)  Public comments. 
(10)  Adjournment. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-09, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-50. - Minutes. 
(a)  The clerk of the board shall promptly record the minutes for each gathering of a quorum of the members of the board or of any committee of its members created by the board, which shall serve as the official written record thereof and shall be open for public inspection once approved as official by the board but in no case later than immediately following the next regular meeting of the board. The minutes shall specify the names of commissioners present at the meeting, a description of each motion or other proposal made at the meeting, the commissioner who proposed each motion, the commissioner who seconded each motion and a record of all votes. In the case of a roll-call vote, the name of each commissioner voting for or against a proposal shall be recorded. It shall be presumed that a commissioner has voted in the affirmative unless the minutes show otherwise. More detailed information may be included in the minutes at the request of the board. 
(b)  The board must approve the minutes before they can be considered as an official record of the board. A copy of the minutes from the previous meeting shall be distributed to the commissioners at least one business day before the following meeting. The minutes of the previous meeting shall be corrected and approved by the board at the beginning of each meeting. A majority vote of the board is required for approval. Conflicts about the content of the minutes shall be decided by majority vote of the board. Upon being approved, the minutes shall be signed by the commissioners and attested by the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-08, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 2-51. - Agenda. 
(a)  The county administrator, with the advice of the chairperson and the commissioners, shall prepare an agenda of subjects to be acted on for each meeting. An agenda work session shall be held by the board of commissioners to discuss and debate items then on the agenda. The chairperson and all commissioners shall participate in the work session. Whenever a quorum of the board is present for an agenda work session, the meeting shall be open to the public and all notice requirements applicable to an open meeting must be met. 
(b)  In order to make a considered and informed decision addressing issues which come before the commission, the agenda for the commission meeting shall be finalized during work sessions. Additions to an agenda for the commission meeting following a work session require the unanimous approval of all commissioners. The commission seeks through this procedure to balance the interest of accessibility to the public with the benefit of members of the commission and the public knowing with certainty what items will come before the commission at its regularly scheduled monthly meetings. A new subject that requires urgent attention may be added to the agenda during a meeting of the commission by the unanimous consent of the board. 
(c)  Members of the public may request that a particular subject be placed on the agenda for a commission meeting. To be considered, any such request must be submitted in writing to the county administrator and received no later than noon (12:00 p.m.) two business days before the regularly scheduled work session, and the request must be specific about the subject requested for placement on the agenda. By way of example, a request for placement of an item on the agenda for a work session scheduled for Tuesday night must be delivered prior to 12:00 noon on the preceding Friday. 
(d)  The order of the agenda may be changed during a meeting by a majority vote of the board. 
(e)  A copy of the agenda and a list of those members present shall be made available to the public for inspection within two business days of the adjournment of any meeting. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-07, 11-13-95; Mo. of 5-10-99) 
Sec. 2-52. - Suspending the rules of order. 
Rules of order may be suspended in the case of an emergency. Rules governing quorum, voting methods and requirements, the notification to commissioners of meetings and rules necessary for compliance with state law cannot be suspended. 
(Ord. No. 96-01, § 1-17, 11-13-95) 
Secs. 2-53—2-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Expenditure of county funds for insurance and employment benefits, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-11.1; employment of additional temporary personnel and equipment for assistance of county officers or departments, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-11; civil service system for county employees authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ I; O.C.G.A. § 36-1-21; Fair Employment Practices Act of 1978, O.C.G.A. § 45-19-20 et seq.; random drug testing of state employees in high-risk jobs, O.C.G.A. § 45-20-90 et seq.; municipal or county governments not to require residence as condition of employment, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-5; Public Employee Hazardous Chemical Protection and Right to Know Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 45-22-1 et seq.; Drug-free Public Work Force Act of 1990, O.C.G.A. § 45-23-1 et seq.; social security coverage for employees of the state and political subdivisions of the state, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-76. - Employee ethics and conduct. 
(a)  Generally. Because public employees are in positions created for the public and funded by the public, the public has the right to expect that the incumbents in these positions will not abuse the trust placed in them by the public. Tift County employees are expected to observe and honor all federal, state and local laws. 
(b)  Political activity. Every county employee is entitled to exercise his/her right to vote. Employees may join or affiliate with civic organizations of a partisan or political nature, attend political meetings, advocate and support the principles and policies of civic or political organizations in accordance with federal, state, and local laws; however, neither an employee's position nor county time shall be used for political purposes, nor should any employee actively campaign for any candidate or issue. 
(c)  Prohibited activity. No employee shall: 
(1)  Engage in any political or partisan activity during working hours; 
(2)  Use official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or a nomination for office; 
(3)  Be required as a duty of employment or as a condition of employment, promotion, or tenure in office to contribute funds for political or partisan purposes, to solicit funds, or act as a custodian of funds for political purposes; 
(4)  Coerce or compel contributions for political or partisan purposes by another employee of the county; 
(5)  Use any supplies, materials or equipment of the county for political or partisan purposes or to aid a political candidate, party, or cause; 
(6)  Wear his/her county uniform for political purposes or to aid a political candidate, party or cause; or 
(7)  Campaign on county premises, which means that employees shall not give out information or attempt to coerce or influence other county employees or the public. Employees shall not wear partisan political badges or buttons while on duty. Employees may display a political sticker on their private automobile, subject to work related instances. 
Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed improper conduct and such employee shall be subject to disciplinary action. 
(d)  Running for local political office prohibited. County employees may not campaign nor run for local political office in the county. For purposes of this section, "local political office" shall mean any elective office in the county government, any City [of Tift] elective office, and the county board of education. 
Any county employee intending to become a candidate for any political office shall, upon qualifying as a candidate for nomination or election, resign from his or her position with the county, or shall be placed on leave without pay until such time as the election for which he/she is a candidate is finally decided; provided, however, that the employee may elect to use annual leave until such leave is depleted, at which time the employee would be placed on leave without pay until such time as the election for which he/she is a candidate is finally decided. 
Failure or refusal of an employee to resign or be placed on leave without pay or to use annual leave as described above upon qualifying as a candidate for nomination or election shall result in the dismissal of the employee. 
(Ord. of 2-12-96) 
Sec. 2-77. - Purchasing card and credit card use by elected officials. 
(a)  Intent and scope. This section is intended to comply with the policy requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24 regarding the use of county issued government purchasing cards and credit cards. 
(b)  Definitions. 
Authorized elected official means an elected official designated by public vote of the board of commissioners to receive a county issued government purchasing card or credit card. 
Card administrator means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the county board of commissioners as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24(c)(6). 
County means Tift County and/or the board of commissioners. 
County purchase card, county p-card or county credit card means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a county official to purchase goods, services and other things of value on behalf of the county. 
Financial transaction card means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). 
User agreement means the required agreement between the board of commissioners and the authorized elected officials which restricts the use of a county purchasing card or credit card. 
(c)  Designated elected officials. The county board of commissioners ("county"), in its discretion, may authorize specific county elected officials to use a county purchasing card or credit card by adoption of a resolution in a public meeting. 
No authorized elected official may use a county purchasing card or credit card until and unless he or she has executed the county's purchasing card and credit card user agreement. 
The county will not make payments to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards that are not issued pursuant to this section or for any purchases that are not authorized by this section. 
(d)  Card administrator. 
The board of commissioners designates the county manager or his designee as purchasing card and credit card administrator. The responsibilities of the card administrator include: 
(1)  Manage county issued purchasing cards and credit cards. 
(2)  Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues. 
(3)  Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of the purchasing card or credit card. 
(4)  Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff. 
(5)  Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards. 
(6)  Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary. 
(7)  Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this section, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24. 
(8)  Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards. 
(9)  Audit and reconcile transactions monthly. 
(10)  Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. 
(e)  Use of cards. 
(1)  Authorized purchases. County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official only. All purchases are subject to the terms of this section, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, county procurement policies and ordinances, and the adopted budget. 
Only authorized elected officials may use a county purchase card or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards, and use of the cards, are not transferrable to employees. The authorized elected official shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date and security code. 
Unless otherwise approved by the governing authority or established in the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the transaction limits shall be those card limits set at the time of issuance. 
(2)  Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. 
(3)  Receipts and documentation . Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. 
(4)  Public records. All receipt and other documentation of purchases are public records and subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. 
(f)  Review of purchases and audit. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls and other measures prevent and allow detection to misuse or abuse of county issued purchase cards and credit cards. All authorized elected officials and their appointed staff that process payments under this program shall cooperate and comply with the procedures established by the county. 
(1)  Review of purchases. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedures internally set to ensure adequate check and balance of card use. 
(2)  Audits. The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures and documentation for transactions. Elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. 
(g)  Violations. 
(1)  An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this section or the user agreement. 
(2)  In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this section may result in: 
a.  A warning; 
b.  Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; or 
c.  Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card. 
(3)  Nothing in this section shall preclude the county governing authority from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card for prosecution to the appropriate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, §§ I—VI, 12-14-15) 
Cross reference— Personnel, ch. 82. 
Secs. 2-78—2-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COUNTY MANAGER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 2003-05, adopted Oct. 13, 2003, amended the title of Div. 2 to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2 was titled "County Administrator". Sections 2—11 of said ordinance amended §§ 2-91—2-100 in their entirety to read as herein set out and § 12 added § 2-101. Former §§ 2-91—2-100 derived from an ordinance of May 14, 1990. 
State Law reference— County manager authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-22. 

Sec. 2-91. - Creation of office; appointment; removal; ineligibility. 
There is hereby created the office of county manager of Tift County. The county manager shall be appointed by a majority vote of the board of commissioners for a period of one year or on such other terms as the board of commissioners may adopt by contract; however, he/she may be removed at the pleasure of the board of commissioners as outlined in this article or as provided by contract. No member of the board of commissioners shall be appointed county manager during the term of office for which he/she is elected. No person related by blood or marriage within the third degree to any member of the board of commissioners shall be eligible for appointment as county manager. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 2, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-92. - Qualifications. 
The county manager shall have the following qualifications: 
(a)  A degree in business administration, public administration or other related fields, together with at least three years experience as a city or county manager or assistant city or county manager; or 
(b)  Comparable training, educational and professional experience which the board of commissioners deems to be appropriate so as to qualify the county manager for the responsibility and duties set forth in section 2-93 below. The commission in making this determination shall determine that the county manager has a knowledge and level of competency commonly associated with the completion of a degree in business or public administration, together with experience sufficiently to thoroughly understand the diverse objectives and functions of the subunits of county government in order to direct and coordinate work within the county government. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 3, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-93. - Job description. 
The county manager shall be the administrative head of the county government. The manager shall be responsible to the board for the proper and efficient administration of all affairs of the county, except as otherwise provided by law. 
(a)  Duties. 
(1)  Direct and supervise all appointed department heads of Tift County in the performance of their assigned duties: to appoint, with the consent of the board of commissioners and when necessary suspend, discharge, transfer or remove, with the consent of the board of commissioners, all appointed department heads with the exception of the county attorney, the auditor, and the clerk, who shall be appointed and discharged directly by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  Require reports from the heads of departments and other employees trusted with administrative duties or exercising discretion. 
(3)  Assist all county elected officials, as well as, those department heads of the county whose duties and responsibilities are not under the direct control and supervision of the board, but who are dependent upon appropriations, in whole or in part, of the board for their continued operation. 
(4)  Be responsible for the preparation and administration of the county budget. 
(5)  Attend all meetings of the board with the right to take part in the discussion, provided the manager shall have no vote before the board. 
(6)  Submit to the board of commissioners, as often as required, a complete report of the finances of the county and make such recommendations as he/she may deem necessary or desirable to meet present and future financial needs of the county. 
(7)  Recommend to the board of commissioners such personnel policies regarding work schedules, pay schedules, vacation and sick leave, as may be consistent with the law and basic policies of the board. 
(8)  Recommend to the board of commissioners adoption of such policies as may be deemed necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the community. 
(9)  Submit the salaries of all officers and employees of the county, whom he/she has the right to appoint; subject, however, to supervision, control or disapproval by the board. 
(10)  Submit to the board at the end of each fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the county for the preceding year. 
(11)  See that all ordinances, resolutions and mandates adopted by the board of commissioners are enforced and duly carried out and complied with in accordance with such legislation, programs, regulations or plans. 
(12)  See that legislation, programs, regulations or plans promulgated and required by the state or federal government are duly carried out in accordance with the direction of the board. 
(13)  Supervise the performance of all contracts made by any person for work done for the county and to supervise and regulate all purchases of materials and supplies for the county within such limitations and under such rules and regulations as may be imposed by the board of commissioners. 
(14)  Have care and custody of all building and of all real and personal property of the county government. 
(15)  Coordinate with business and development community to increase industrial development in the county. 
(b)  Knowledge, skills, and abilities. 
(1)  Knowledge of the principles and practices of public administration. 
(2)  Knowledge of the county code of ordinances and other regulations, policies, and procedures. 
(3)  Knowledge of budget preparation and finance. 
(4)  Knowledge of the functions, organization, and operations of all county departments. 
(5)  Knowledge of the county's demographic and economic profile, including its industrial base. 
(6)  Knowledge of the principles and practices of effective public relations. 
(7)  Knowledge of the state and federal laws in all areas applicable to county government including unemployment, wages, hours, EEOC, taxes, workers compensation, pensions, and others. 
(8)  Skill in written and oral communications. 
(9)  Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with the county's elected officers and appointed department heads, other county employees and the general public. 
(c)  Supervisory controls. The chairperson of the board of commissioners, assigns work on the basis of standing goals, objectives, and priorities. The manager must use much judgment in deciding how to accomplish goals. The supervisor provides guidance for problematic situations and spot checks work for the nature and propriety of final results. 
(d)  Guidelines. Guidelines consist of all county ordinances, applicable state and federal laws, grant application instructions, county policies and procedures, and directives from the board of commissioners. These guidelines require selection, judgment, and interpretation in application. 
(e)  Complexity. The purpose of this position is to manage all phases of county government. The work is made complex by the multitude and variety of tasks to be completed and by the necessity for dealing with public input which can be conflicting or critical. 
(f)  Scope and effect. The purpose of this position is to assist the county commissioners in seeing that the county's government operates according to state laws and county ordinances. Successful performance in this position facilities work of all county departments, assures that grant monies are obtained and spent properly, assures that county services are delivered efficiently, and that county records are properly retained. 
(g)  Personal contacts. Contacts are typically with co-workers, employees in all county departments, member of the board of commissioners, employees of the State of Georgia, representatives of organizations, and the public at large. 
(h)  Physical demands. Work is performed with employee intermittently sitting, standing or stooping. 
(i)  Work environment. Work is performed in an office and the field. 
(j)  Supervisory and management responsibility. The position has direct supervision over all administrative personnel and all department heads. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 4, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-94. - Reports. 
The board of commissioners shall have the right to require the county manager to appear before it at any time and make such reports, oral or written, as it deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 5, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-95. - Bond. 
At the election of the board of commissioners, the county manager may be required to execute and deliver a good and sufficient bond conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. The bond shall be payable to the county and shall be in such amount and on such terms as may be prescribed by the board. Should a bond be required by the board of commissioners, it shall be filed by the county clerk in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Tift County. Any premium due on such bond shall be paid by the county fiscal officer out of county funds. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 6, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-96. - Oath. 
Before entering upon his duties, the county manager shall take and subscribe an oath for the faithful performance of his duties under this article, which oath shall be duly entered upon the minutes of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 7, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-97. - Suspension or removal. 
The county manager may be suspended or removed at the pleasure of the county board of commissioners by a majority vote of such board, subject to the terms of any applicable contract of employment. In case of suspension or removal, the county manager shall be given a written statement of the reasons for such action. He may, within five days from receipt of such statement, request a public hearing thereon before the county board of commissioners. Upon receipt of such request, a hearing shall be set not earlier than ten days nor later than 15 days from the date of such request. Pending such hearing, and until final action has been taken thereon, the county manager may be suspended from office and all of the duties thereof performed by some other person designated by the county board of commissioners to perform such duties. After such hearing the board of commissioners, by majority vote, may reinstate or terminate the employment of the county manager. The action of the board of commissioners in suspending or removing the county manager shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 8, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-98. - Political activities. 
The county manager shall not engage in or be concerned with any local partisan politics or any local political campaign. He shall not contribute to or solicit funds for any local political purposes from any other person. He shall not appoint any relative as an employee of the county. He shall not be eligible for election as a member of the county board of commissioners for a period of four years after termination of his service as county manager. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 9, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-99. - Compensation. 
The county manager shall be paid an annual salary to be fixed by the board of commissioners of the county and there shall be no reduction of such salary during his term of office. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 10, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-100. - Authority to deal with securities. 
The county manager with regard to any SPLOST (special purpose local option sales tax) authorized by voters of Tift County is authorized and empowered for or on behalf of the board of commissioners of the county to establish and maintain one or more accounts, which may be margin accounts, with Nations Bank Capital Markets, Inc. (NCMI) for the purposes of purchasing, investing in or otherwise acquiring, selling (including short sales), possessing, transferring, exchanging, pledging or otherwise disposing of, or turning to the account of or realizing upon and generally dealing in and with any and all forms of securities including, but not by way of limitation, shares, stocks, bonds, debentures, notes, scrip, participation certificates, rights to subscribed, option, warrants, certificates of deposit, mortgages, evidences of indebtedness, commercial paper, foreign exchange contracts, commodities, community futures, certificates of indebtedness and certificates of interest of any and every kind and nature whatsoever, secured or unsecured, whether represented by trust, participating and/or other certificates otherwise, on margin or otherwise. This agreement shall also insure to the benefit of NCMI's successors, by merger, consolidation or otherwise, and assigns, and NCMI may transfer our account to any such successors or assigns. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 11, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-101. - Amendment to inconsistent ordinances. 
Any ordinances existing at the time of passage of this division by the board of commissioners and in conflict in any manner with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby amended so as remove any inconsistency. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 12, 10-13-03) 
Secs. 2-102—2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COUNTY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-121. - Roles and responsibilities. 
(a)  The primary function of the county attorney is to provide legal advice and representations of the county. As a part of that function, the county attorney's duties include advising and representing the county board of commissioners as the governing authority of the county, the county sheriff's office, the county commissioners' office, clerk of superior court, probate court judge and other officials and employees of the county. The county attorney's duties also include advising the county commissioners and other county officers and employees of their powers and duties under the laws of the state, to prepare ordinances and legal documents, to review proposed contracts, and to represent the county and its officers in legal proceedings. 
(b)  The county desires to improve and clarify the proper role and duties of the county attorney in the representation of county officers and employees of the county. 
(c)  The county is committed to providing proper and adequate legal representation to each and every official and employee of the county for actions taken pursuant to their official duties. 
(d)  Where there is a legal conflict of interest which would prevent the county attorney from providing legal representation or where simultaneous or dual representation by the county attorney or any official or employee of the county and the county commission creates a legal conflict of interest, the county should provide for separate and independent legal representation of the county official or employee. 
(e)  The county attorney is a member of the State Bar of Georgia and is therefore sworn to uphold mandated requirements of ethics and professionalism. As such, the county attorney should seek to fully inform the county commission and any affected official or employee of the county of all decisions which effect the resolution of disputes requiring resolution. 
(f)  The county attorney is required to fully inform the county commission and effected officials or employees of the county concerning the need of any representation, and most particularly communicate the terms or the proposed terms of the settlement of any dispute. 
(g)  The county attorney should counsel and advise the county commission and any effected county official or employee on the value of cooperation and flexibility as a means towards the judicious resolution of disputes. 
(Res. of 1-9-95) 
Secs. 2-122—2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-141. - County appointees. 
(a)  All persons appointed by the board of commissioners of Tift County to serve on its various authorities, boards and commissions shall take an oath of office before the commission to attend all meetings and to well and truly perform the duties attendant to such position to the best of their skill and ability. 
(b)  Appointees of the board of commissioners shall be removed for cause or for failure to attend three consecutive meetings or 60 percent of the meetings of the authority, board or commission [as applicable] without medical excuse. 
(c)  Any appointees removed under the provisions of this section shall be entitled to petition the board of commissioners for reinstatement for good and valid cause. 
(Res. No. 2004-14, 10-11-04) 
Secs. 2-142—2-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GREATER TIFT COUNTY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.; authority to adopt plans and exercise zoning powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV. 

Sec. 2-156. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means any individual or business entity applying for rezoning action. 
Business entity means any corporation, partnership, limited partnership firm, enterprise, franchise, association or trust. 
Commission means the Greater Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission. 
Financial interest means all direct or indirect ownership interest of the total assets or capital stock of a business entity where such ownership interest is ten percent or more. 
Governing authorities means collectively the board of commissioners, the city commission of the City of Tifton and the city commission of the City of Omega. 
Governing authority of the City of Tifton means the city commission of the City of Tifton, Georgia. 
Governing authority of the City of Omega means the mayor and council of the City of Omega, Georgia. 
Governing authority of Tift County means the board of commissioners. 
Governing authority for the City of Ty Ty means the mayor and council of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. 
Member means a member of the commission. 
Member of the family means the spouse, mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter of a member. 
Property interest means the direct or indirect ownership of real property and includes any percentage of ownership less than total ownership as well as both legal and equitable interest. 
Real property means any tract or parcel of land and, if developed, any buildings or structures located on the land. 
Rezoning action means action by one of the governmental entities adopting or rejecting a proposed amendment to the zoning ordinance or zoning map of the governmental entity which would have the effect of rezoning real property from one zoning classification to another. 
Zoning Ordinance of Omega means the zoning ordinance of the City of Omega as hereafter adopted and as thereafter amended. 
Zoning Ordinance of Tift County means the zoning ordinance of the county adopted February 27, 1990, as now and hereafter amended. 
Zoning Ordinance of Tifton means the zoning ordinance of the City of Tifton adopted October 6, 1986, as now and hereafter amended. 
Zoning Ordinance of Ty Ty means the zoning ordinance of the city as adopted and thereafter amended. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.2; Ord. No. 2000-01, § 1, 3-13-00) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-157. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established the Greater Tift County Planning Commission which shall function in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.3) 
Sec. 2-158. - Membership; selection procedure. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of 12 members who shall be selected from time to time as follows: 
(1)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of Tift County for an initial term expiring December 31, 1991, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as county post number one. 
(2)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of Tift County for an initial term expiring December 31, 1992, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as county post number two. 
(3)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of Tift County for an initial term expiring December 31, 1993, and with five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as county post number three. 
(4)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of Tift County for an initial term expiring December 31, 1994, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as county post number four. 
(5)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of Tift County for an initial term expiring December 31, 1995, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as county post number five. 
(6)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Tifton for an initial term expiring December 31, 1991, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Tifton post number one. 
(7)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Tifton for an initial term expiring December 31, 1992, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Tifton post number two. 
(8)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Tifton for an initial term expiring December 31, 1993, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Tifton post number three. 
(9)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Tifton for an initial term expiring December 31, 1994, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Tifton post number four. 
(10)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Tifton for an initial term expiring December 31, 1995, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Tifton post number five. 
(11)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Omega for an initial term expiring December 31, 1995, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Omega post number one. 
(12)  One member shall be selected from time to time by the governing authority of the City of Ty Ty for an initial term expiring December 31, 2004, and five-year terms thereafter with such position to be designated as Ty Ty post number one. 
(b)  All vacancies which shall from time to time exist shall be filled for the unexpired term thereof by the respective governing authority which selected the member whose position shall become vacant. 
(c)  Members shall, notwithstanding their terms of office, serve at the pleasure of the governing authority which selected each such member and each member shall be subject to removal prior to the termination of his term by action of the governing authority which so selected such member. 
(d)  Upon selection and commencement of his term, each member shall serve, subject to death or resignation and subject to removal, until both the selection of and the commencement of the term of his successor. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.4; Ord. No. 2000-01, § 2, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 2-159. - Compensation. 
Members shall receive no compensation for their services except that they may be reimbursed for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred by them in direct connection with the performances of their services and duties, subject to approval thereof by the governing authorities or the governing authority of the governmental entity on behalf of which the member shall have function in accordance with such requirements as shall be imposed in connection therewith from time to time by resolutions of the governing authorities or of the governing authority of the governmental entity on behalf of which the member shall function. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.5) 
Sec. 2-160. - Meetings. 
Meetings of the commission shall be held from time to time as necessary for the commission to perform its duties and responsibilities, with meetings to be held at least once per month on a regularly scheduled day and at a regularly scheduled time and place, as determined from time to time by majority vote of the members of the commission. Meetings shall also be held upon call by the chairperson, or by a majority of the members. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public and shall be held in accordance with the requirements of state law relative to open public meetings. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.6) 
Sec. 2-161. - Disclosure of financial interest. 
A member of the commission who: 
(1)  Has a property interest in any real property affected by any proposed rezoning action pending before the commission; 
(2)  Has a financial interest in any business entity which has a property interest in any real property affected by any proposed rezoning action pending before the commission; or 
(3)  Has a member of the family who has any interest described in either subsection (1) or subsection (2) of this section shall, at or prior to the initial meeting of the commission at which the matter is to be considered, disclose the nature and extent of such interest in writing to the applicant and to the commission. All such disclosures shall be entered into the minutes of meetings of the commission, but in no event later than immediately following the announcement of the matter for consideration by the commission, and shall be matters of public record of both the commission and the governmental entity involved and shall be available for public inspection at any time during normal working hours. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.7) 
Sec. 2-162. - Disclosure of contributions. 
(a)  When any applicant for any proposed rezoning action has made, within two years immediately preceding the filing of that applicant's application for the rezoning action, gifts having in the aggregate a value of $250.00 or more to any member, it shall be the duty of the applicant or the attorney representing the applicant to disclose in writing to the commission: 
(1)  The name of members to whom the gifts were made; and 
(2)  An enumeration and description of each gift having a value of $250.00 or more made by the applicant to each such member during the two years immediately preceding the filing of the application for the zoning change. 
(b)  The disclosures required by subsection (a) of this section shall be filed within ten days after the application for the proposed rezoning action is first filed. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.8) 
Sec. 2-163. - Disclosure of relationships. 
Each member who shall have any business or financial relationship with any applicant or with any owner of any property proposed for rezoning action and who, due to the nature or extent of such relationship or relationships, may not be able to objectively act with respect to the proposed rezoning action shall, at or prior to the initial meeting of the commission at which the matter is to be considered, but in no event later than immediately following the announcement of the matter for consideration by the commission, disclose the nature and extent of such relationships to the applicant and to the commission. All such disclosures shall be entered into the minutes of the commission, shall be matters of public record of both the commission and the governmental entity involved and shall be available for public inspection at any time during normal working hours. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.9) 
Sec. 2-164. - Disqualification of members. 
(a)  Any member who shall have a property interest, a financial interest, or a member of the family who has either a property interest or financial interest which is subject to disclosure pursuant to the provisions of this division; shall have received any contribution which is subject to disclosure pursuant to the provisions of this division; or shall have any relationship which is subject to disclosure pursuant to the provisions of this division may disqualify himself from participation in the consideration of the proposed rezoning action in issue or may be disqualified by vote of the commission, as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Any other member, the applicant and any other interested person shall each be entitled at the time of the call for consideration of the matter or at any time prior thereto to raise any issue of possible disqualification of any member whereupon, following such consideration as the commission shall deem appropriate, the commission shall determine by majority vote of those members who are not subject to potential disqualification in connection with the proposed rezoning action whether the member shall be disqualified. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.10) 
Sec. 2-165. - Duties and responsibilities. 
The commission shall function only in an advisory capacity to each of the respective governing authorities. In connection therewith, the commission shall, subject to the direction, control and instructions of the respective governing authority of each governmental entity, conduct surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and shall develop plans for physical, social and economic growth which will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, general welfare, efficiency and economy in the development of the governmental entity involved and submit the same to the governing authority of each governmental entity, and shall also, subject to the direction, control and instructions of the respective governing authority of each governmental entity: 
(1)  Develop and submit to the governing authority of each governmental entity for its consideration of a master plan, and amendments thereto, for the development of each governmental entity. 
(2)  Develop and submit to the governing authority of each governmental entity for its consideration recommendations relative to amendments to or revisions of the zoning ordinances and zoning maps of the governmental entity. 
(3)  Review proposed amendments to or revisions of the zoning ordinances and zoning maps of each of the respective governmental entities which shall be submitted by others, make findings with respect thereto, and make recommendations to the governing authority of the governmental entity involved with respect to the adoption, rejection, modification or conditional adoption of each such proposed amendment or revision. 
(4)  Develop and submit to the governing authority of each governmental entity for its consideration regulations and amendments thereto for the subdivision of land. 
(5)  Develop and submit to the governing authority of each governmental entity for its consideration official maps or plats, and amendments thereto, which designate the exact location of the boundary lines of existing, proposed, extended, widened and narrowed streets, public ways, public open spaces and public buildings and sites together with regulations and amendments thereto for the erection of buildings and other structures to be located therein. 
(6)  Perform such additional functions and services for and on behalf of each governmental entity as shall be authorized or directed from time to time by the governing authority thereof. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.11) 
Sec. 2-166. - Adoption of rules and regulations. 
The commission shall adopt such rules, policies, procedures and regulations as shall not be inconsistent with the provisions of this division, the zoning ordinances of the governmental entities and applicable law. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.12) 
Sec. 2-167. - Chairperson and vice-chairperson. 
The commission shall annually select from among its members a chairperson who shall preside at meetings of the commission and a vice-chairperson who shall preside at meetings of the commission in the absence of the chairperson or the disqualification of the chairperson. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.13) 
Sec. 2-168. - Secretaries of commission—Generally. 
(a)  The secretary of the commission with respect to matters relative to Tift County and the zoning ordinance of Tift County shall be the zoning administrator of Tift County or his designee or such other person or official as shall from time to time be so designated by the county administrator of Tift County to perform the functions of secretary of the commission on behalf of Tift County or his designee. 
(b)  The secretary of the commission with respect to matters relative to the City of Tifton and the zoning ordinance of the City of Tifton shall be the city clerk of the City of Tifton or his designee or such other person or official as shall from time to time be so designated by the city manager of the City of Tifton to perform the functions of secretary of the commission on behalf of the City of Tifton or his designee. 
(c)  The secretary of the commission with respect to matters relative to the City of Omega and the zoning ordinance of the City of Omega shall be the zoning administrator of the City of Omega or his designee or such other person or official as shall from time to time be so designated by the mayor of the City of Omega to perform the functions of secretary of the commission on behalf of the City of Omega or his designee. 
(d)  The secretary of the commission with respect to matters relative to the City of Ty Ty and the zoning ordinance of the City of Ty Ty (or his/her designee or such other person or official as shall from time to time be so designated by the mayor of the city to perform the functions of secretary of the commission on behalf of the city or his/her designee) shall be the zoning administrator of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.14; Ord. No. 2000-01, § 3, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 2-169. - Same—Duties. 
The respective secretaries of the commission shall provide administrative assistance to the commission relative to matters relating to each of their respective governmental entities and specifically shall, with respect to matters which are relative to their respective governmental entities: 
(1)  Prepare and conduct all correspondence of the commission. 
(2)  Receive and file all correspondence to the commission. 
(3)  Receive and file all applications and filings to and with the commission. 
(4)  Receive and file all transmittals to the commission from the zoning administrator of the governmental entity and other public officials. 
(5)  Review and evaluate all applications and filings to and with the commission for compliance with the rules and regulations of the commission and notify those filing the same of any noncompliance therewith. 
(6)  Following consultation with the chairperson, and to the extent necessary with the other members, schedule meetings of the commission in accordance with applicable law, ordinances, resolutions and the rules and regulations of the commission. 
(7)  Prepare and maintain a calendar and docket of proposed rezoning actions before the commission. 
(8)  Prepare and submit to the members at least 24 hours prior to a scheduled hearing an agenda therefor as well as copies of all applications and other filings made in connection with each such proceeding. 
(9)  Determine all notices to be given in connection with proceedings before the commission and cause such notices to be given to those entitled thereto. 
(10)  Attend all meetings and hearings of the commission. 
(11)  Cause a mechanical record to be made of all meetings and hearings of the commission relative to proposed rezoning actions by use of tape recorder or other appropriate device. 
(12)  Cause to be retained and maintained a copy or a facsimile of all physical evidence presented in connection with proposed rezoning actions. 
(13)  Prepare and maintain minutes of proceedings of the commission indicating therein all significant information, matters and facts pertaining thereto including specifically all motions, votes and decisions of the commission together with the vote of each member upon each such motion, vote and decision including those absent, disqualified or failing to vote thereon together with such other matters as shall be pertinent to the activities of the commission. 
(14)  Cause to be retained and maintained all minutes, records, files and notices of the commission. 
(15)  Attempt, at hearings of the commission with respect to proposed rezoning actions, to obtain the name and address of all persons who shall present any evidence, testimony or opinions, and make any statement to the commission or present any argument in connection with the matter before the commission. 
(16)  Perform such other duties as shall be directed from time to time by the commission which is approved by the chief administrative official of the governmental entity. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.15) 
Sec. 2-170. - Authority. 
The commission shall have no authority or power other than as specifically provided from time to time by ordinance or resolution of the governing authorities and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, shall have no authority, right or power to expend any funds; to direct the activities of any employee or official of any of the governmental entities, except solely the secretaries of the commission and then only to the extent specifically authorized in this division; or to contract for or on behalf of either itself or any of the governmental entities. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.16) 
Sec. 2-171. - Legal assistance. 
(a)  With respect to the zoning ordinance of the City of Tifton and matters relative to the City of Tifton, the city attorney of the City of Tifton shall act as the legal advisor and representative of the commission and shall render such legal assistance to the commission as shall be necessary. 
(b)  With respect to the zoning ordinance of the City of Omega and matters relative to the City of Omega, the city attorney of the City of Omega shall act as the legal advisor and representative of the commission and shall render such legal assistance to the commission as shall be necessary. 
(c)  With respect to the zoning ordinance of Tift County and matters relative to Tift County, the county attorney of Tift County shall act as the legal advisor and representative of the commission and shall render such legal assistance to the commission as shall be necessary. 
(d)  With respect to the zoning ordinance of the City of Ty Ty and matters relative to the City of Ty Ty, the city attorney of the City of Ty Ty shall act as the legal advisor and representative of the council and shall render such legal assistance to the council as shall be necessary. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.17; Ord. No. 2000-01, § 4, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 2-172. - Decisions. 
Decisions of the commission as to its recommendations on applications for rezoning action shall be rendered by majority vote of members who are not disqualified to vote thereon which shall be made either at the time of the consideration thereof or at a later public meeting of the commission as to which notice has been given to those entitled thereto. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.18) 
Sec. 2-173. - Minutes and records. 
All minutes, upon approval thereof by the commission, and all files, dockets, calendars, physical evidence, notices and records of the commission which relate to matters with respect to each governmental entity shall be maintained in the office of the clerk or zoning administrator of each governmental entity, as determined from time to time by each governmental entity, subject to court orders relative thereto and subject to public inspection. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.19) 
Sec. 2-174. - Transitional provisions. 
(a)  The adoption of this division and the provisions contained in this section shall not affect or alter the status or validity of any decision or recommendation made by the Tifton-Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission either prior to or subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division derives. 
(b)  All applications for rezoning action and all applications and other requests for amendments to or revisions of the zoning ordinance or zoning map of Tift County or the zoning ordinance or zoning map of the City of Tifton which shall have been filed and heard by the Tifton-Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives shall continue to be considered by the Tifton-Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission in accordance with applicable current ordinances and resolutions following the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives until such matters are finally disposed of by such body. 
(c)  All applications for rezoning action and all applications and other requests for amendments to or revisions of the zoning ordinance or zoning map of Tift County or the zoning ordinance or zoning map of the City of Tifton which have been filed but not heard by the Tifton-Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives as well as all other matters, other than those specified in this section, then under consideration by the Tifton-Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission shall stand by virtue hereof transferred to the commission effective as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(d)  All applications for rezoning action and all applications and other requests for amendments to or revisions of the zoning ordinance or zoning map of Tift County or the zoning ordinance or zoning map of the City of Tifton which are filed on or subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives shall be, and for all purposes shall be deemed to have been, filed with, and shall be considered by the commission. 
(Ord. of 12-10-90, § 1.20) 
Secs. 2-175—2-200. - Reserved.
