ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-86. - Exemption from provisions of Act No. 1046 regarding self-inspections. 
Pursuant to Section 3 of Act No. 1046 [regarding, among other things, that master plumbers and utility contractors may self-inspect their own installation of water and sewer lines,] be it resolved that the board of commissioners does hereby exempt the county from the provisions of said Act codified as O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d). 
(Res. of 5-13-96) 
Secs. 22-87—22-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FLOW RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Flow rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3. 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. 
Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
(Ord. of 2-11-91, § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-102. - Prohibited fixtures. 
On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the city for any building of any type which: 
(1)  Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; 
(2)  Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallons of water per flush; 
(4)  Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or 
(5)  Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. 
(Ord. of 2-11-91, § 2) 
Sec. 22-103. - Repair and renovations. 
The requirements of section 22-102 shall apply to any construction initiated after July 1, 1991, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers, or both. 
(Ord. of 2-11-91, § 4) 
Sec. 22-104. - Exemptions. 
(a)  New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of this article when: 
(1)  The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; 
(2)  When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; 
(3)  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(4)  Units to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles in schools, institutions, etc., not residential. 
(b)  The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsections (a)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall apply for such exemption at the office of the building official. A fee as established by the board of commissioners from time to time shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. 
(Ord. of 2-11-91, § 5) 
Sec. 22-105. - Limitations of division. 
This division shall not apply to any construction of a residential building, the contract for which was entered into prior to July 1, 1991, and shall not apply to any construction of a commercial building the contract for which was entered into prior to July 1, 1992. 
(Ord. of 2-11-91, § 6) 
Secs. 22-106—22-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Water Well Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120. 

Sec. 22-126. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved means accepted by the county. 
Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the premises other than the purveyor's approved public potable water supply. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's public potable water supply or any natural sources such as a well, spring, river, stream, harbor, etc., or used waters or industrial fluids. These waters may be polluted or contaminated or they may be objectionable and constitute an unacceptable water source over which the water purveyor does not have sanitary control. 
Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances under pressure into the distributing pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source. 
Backflow by backpressure means the reverse flow of water caused when the downstream pressure becomes greater than the pressure in the potable water supply system. 
Backflow by backsiphonage means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distributing pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. 
Backflow preventer means a device or means designed to prevent backflow, as follows: 
(1)  Air-gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device and the flood level rim of said vessel. An approved air-gap shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically, above the top of the rim of the vessel, and in no case less than one inch. When an air-gap is used at the service connection to prevent the contamination or pollution of the public potable water system, an emergency bypass shall be installed around the air-gap system and an approved reduced pressure principle device shall be installed in the bypass system. 
(2)  Reduced pressure principle device means an assembly of two independently operating approved check valves with an automatically operating differential relief valve between the two check valves, tightly closing shutoff valves on either side of the check valves, plus properly located test cocks for the testing of the check and relief valves. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications and approval of a recognized and county-approved testing agency for backflow prevention assemblies. The device shall operate to maintain the pressure in the zone between the two check valves at a level less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the device. At cessation of normal flow, the pressure between the two check valves shall be less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the device. In case of leakage of either of the check valves the differential relief valve shall operate to maintain the reduced pressure in the zone between the check valves by discharging to the atmosphere. When the inlet pressure is two pounds per square inch or less, the relief valve shall open to the atmosphere. To be approved, these devices must be readily accessible for in-line maintenance and testing and be installed in a location where no part of the device will be submerged. 
(3)  Double check valve assembly means an assembly of two independently operating approved check valves with tightly closing shutoff valves on each side of the check valves, plus properly located test cocks for the testing of each check valve. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications and approval of a recognized and approved testing agency for backflow prevention devices. To be approved these devices must be readily accessible for in-line maintenance and testing. 
Building official means building official of the county. 
Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree which creates an actual hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease. 
Cross connection means any physical connection or arrangement of piping or fixtures between two otherwise separate piping systems one of which contains potable water and the other nonpotable water or industrial fluids of questionable safety, through which, or because of which, backflow may occur into the potable water system. A water service connection between a public potable water distribution system and a customer's water distribution system which is cross connected to a contaminated fixture, industrial fluid system or with a potentially contaminated supply or auxiliary water system, constitutes one type of cross connection. Other types of cross connections include connectors such as swing connection, removable sections, four-way valves, spools, dummy sections of pipe, swivel or change-over devices, sliding multiport tube, solid connections, etc. 
Cross connection control by containment means the installation of an approved backflow prevention device at the water service connection to any customer's premises where it is physically and economically infeasible to find and permanently eliminate or control all actual or potential cross connections within the customer's water system; or it shall mean the installation of an approved backflow prevention device on the service line leading to and supplying cross connections which cannot be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of cross connection. 
Cross connection control coordinator means the cross connection control coordinator of the county. 
Cross connections, controlled means a connection between a potable water system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow prevention device properly installed that will continuously afford the protection commensurate with the degree of hazard. 
Hazard, degree of means derived from an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system of the county. 
(1)  Hazard, contamination means any condition, device, or practice in the water supply system and its operation which could create or, in the judgement of the county, may create a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. An example of a health hazard is the structural defect, including cross connections, in a water supply system. 
(2)  Hazard, plumbing means a plumbing type cross connection in a consumer's potable water system that has not been properly protected by a vacuum breaker, air-gap separation or backflow prevention device. Unprotected plumbing type cross connections are considered to be a health hazard. 
(3)  Hazard, pollutional means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or to the potability of the public or the consumer's potable water system, but which would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but would not be dangerous to health. 
(4)  Hazard, system means an actual or potential threat of severe damage to the physical properties of the public potable water system or the consumer's potable water system or of a pollution or contamination which would have a protracted effect on the quality of the potable water in the system. 
Industrial fluids system means any system located within the unincorporated area of the county containing a fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, system, pollutional or plumbing hazard if introduced into an approved water system. This may include, but not be limited to: polluted or contaminated waters; all types of process waters and used waters originating from the public potable water system which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; chemicals in fluid form; plating acids and alkalies, circulated cooling waters connected to an open cooling tower and/or cooling towers that are chemically or biologically treated or stabilized with toxic substances; contaminated natural waters such as from wells, springs, streams, rivers, bays, harbors, seas, irrigation canals or systems, etc.; oils, gases, glycerine, paraffins, caustic and acidic solutions and other liquids and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other purposes or for firefighting purposes. 
Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, or biological) in water which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual hazard to the public health, but which does adversely and unreasonably effect such waters for domestic use. 
Water, potable means any water which, according to recognized standards, is safe for human consumption. 
Water, nonpotable means water which is not safe for human consumption or which is of questionable potability. 
Water, service connections means the terminal end of a service connection from the public potable water system; i.e., where the water purveyor loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customer's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection shall mean the downstream end of the meter. There should be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow prevention device located at the point of delivery to the customer's water system. Service connections shall also include water service connections from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the public potable water system. 
Water, used means any water supplied by a water purveyor from a public potable water system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the point of delivery and is no longer under the sanitary control of the water purveyor. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-127. - Regulations. 
To protect the water supply system of the county, the following regulations are adopted: 
(1)  No installation of potable water supply piping or part thereof shall be made in such a manner that it will be possible for used, unclean, polluted or contaminated water, mixtures or substances to enter any portion of such piping from any tank, receptacle, equipment or plumbing fixture by reason of backsiphonage, or any other cause, either during normal use and operation thereof or when any such tank, receptacle, equipment or plumbing fixture is flooded, or subject to pressure in excess of the pressure in the hot or cold water piping. 
(2)  No person shall make a connection or allow one to exist between pipes of conduits carrying domestic water supplied by any public or private water service system; any pipes, conduits or fixtures containing or carrying water from any other source or containing or carrying water which has been used for any purpose whatsoever; or any piping carrying chemicals, liquids, gases, or any substances whatsoever, unless there is provided an approved backflow prevention device. The approval of the county must be obtained before any connection is made between the domestic supply and any contaminated, polluted or auxiliary water system. 
(3)  No plumbing fixture, device or construction shall be installed or maintained or shall be connected to any domestic water supply, when such installation or connection may provide a possibility of polluting such water supply, or may provide a cross connection between a distributing system or water for drinking and domestic purposes and water which may become contaminated by such plumbing fixture device or construction, unless there is provided an approved backflow prevention device. 
(4)  No water piping supplied by any private water supply system or industrial piping system shall be connected to the public potable water system without the approval of the county. 
(5)  No person shall construct, maintain or operate a physical arrangement whereby a public water system is or may be connected directly or indirectly with a nonpotable water system or nonpermitted water system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device which contains or may contain contaminated water, liquified gases, sewage or other waste of unknown or unsafe quality, which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water system as the results of backflow, bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeover devices, or other temporary, permanent or potential connections through which or because of which backflow or backsiphonage could or would occur. 
(6)  A supplier of water or any person having possession or control of facilities which may cause the contamination of the public water system has the responsibility to prevent water from unapproved sources or any contaminants from entering the public water system by such physical arrangements cited in subsection (5) of this section. 
(7)  Any persons connecting to and purchasing water from a public water system and reselling it to others is considered a supplier of the water so purchased as well as a consumer, and is also responsible for the quality of such water. 
(8)  A supplier shall, when requested by the county or the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, develop a control program for the elimination and prevention of all cross connections. A written plan for the program shall be submitted to the county for review and approval within one year or less in accordance with a written request by the county. When the plan is approved, the supplier shall implement the program immediately. 
(9)  The procedures for backflow and backsiphonage prevention and cross connection control shall conform to those recommended by the American Water Works Association, Manual 14, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Cross Connection Manual. 
(10)  Potable water supply piping, water discharge outlets, backflow prevention devices or similar equipment shall be so located as to make impossible their submergence in any contaminated or polluted liquid or substance. 
(11)  The building official shall enforce the provisions of this division so as to ensure the potability of the consumer's water supply, from the point of entrance of the public water supply to the extremities of the consumer's water system. The building official has primary enforcing responsibility of new installations, alterations or repairs of water supply systems. He shall provide the cross connection control coordinator and the water purveyor with the assistance required to enforce the provisions of this division. 
(12)  The water purveyor is primarily responsible for the prevention of contamination and pollution of the public water mains. Such responsibility begins at the point of origin of the public water supply and includes adequate treatment facilities and water mains and ends at the point of entrance to the consumer's water system, provided adequate backflow and backsiphonage protection is maintained on all water supply systems directly connected to the water purveyor's public system. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-3) 
Sec. 22-128. - Enforcement of division. 
(a)  The cross connection control coordinator shall enforce the provisions of this division so as to ensure the potability of the consumer's water supply, from the point of entrance of the public water supply to the extremities of the consumer's water system. He has primary enforcing responsibility of new installations, alterations or repairs of water supply systems. He shall also provide the water purveyor with the assistance required to enforce the provisions of this division on existing water supply systems. 
(b)  The water purveyor is primarily responsible for the prevention of contamination and pollution of the public water mains. Such responsibility begins at the point of origin of the public water supply and includes adequate treatment facilities and water mains, and ends at the point of entrance to the consumer's water system, provided adequate backflow and backsiphonage protection is maintained on all water supply systems directly connected to the water purveyor's public system. 
(c)  The cross connection control coordinator is responsible for supervising the prevention of contamination and pollution of the public water main, all water supply systems and all water sources. Such responsibility extends from the point of origin of the public water supply to and including all extremities of the consumer's supply and its actual use. He has prime supervisory responsibility for administration and enforcement of those portions of the cross connection control and backflow prevention program applicable to existing water supply systems and water sources. 
(d)  The consumer has the prime responsibility of preventing contaminants and pollutants from entering the water supply system from his water supply system. The consumer shall protect his water supply system against actual or potential cross connection, and possible backflow conditions as required by this division and other applicable regulations. He shall ensure the necessary plumbing permits are obtained for new water supply system installations, and for alterations or repair to existing systems, as required by this division. All work and connections shall be done by an approved plumbing contractor. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-4) 
Sec. 22-129. - Certification of backflow prevention device testers. 
(a)  A person wishing to become certified as a backflow prevention device tester must complete a comprehensive training program approved by the county. If an individual wishes to be placed on the county's list of approved backflow prevention device testers, he must submit his request in writing to the cross connection control coordinator with a copy of his certificate of completion. The county shall notify the individual in writing as to his approval or denial. (See Appendix, form F). 
(b)  The cross connection control coordinator may, from time to time, establish additional or alternate requirements for an individual's name to be placed on the county's list of approved backflow prevention device testers. The additional or alternate requirements shall be consistent with the intent of the program. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-7) 
Sec. 22-130. - Existing facilities. 
(a)  All premises of the type where cross connections are suspect shall be surveyed by the county to determine if a detailed inspection will be required. 
(b)  The owners of the suspected premises shall be notified in writing 30 days in advance to secure an appointment for inspection of the premises. (See Appendix, form letter A). The owner or his authorized representative will be required to accompany the inspector during the tour of the premises. 
(c)  An inspection form will be completed by the inspector and signed by the owner or his representative. (See Appendix, form B). The owner shall be made aware of any corrective measures that need to be made. 
(d)  All official letters of notification shall be sent to the owner indicating what corrective measures must be taken. (See Appendix, form C). 
(e)  Upon conformance of the requirements in the notification letter, the owner shall immediately notify the county to schedule a date for reinspection. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-5) 
Sec. 22-131. - New facilities. 
(a)  Each applicant for a county or city building permit that will connect to the public water system of the county will be required to complete a questionnaire. (See Appendix, form D). 
(b)  The building official shall forward a copy of the questionnaire along with blueprint of proposed construction to the cross connection control coordinator. 
(c)  The cross connection control coordinator will notify the new customer in writing and arrange a meeting to discuss the requirements for backflow prevention. Procedures for inspection of the device will be discussed at this meeting. (See Appendix, form E). 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-6) 
Sec. 22-132. - Testing, maintenance and inspection. 
(a)  The owner of a backflow prevention device shall be notified 30 days in advance by the cross connection control coordinator as to when his device will require inspection. (See Appendix, form G). 
(b)  Attached to the notification letter mentioned in subsection (a) of this section shall be a test and maintenance form which must be completed by the owner's certified backflow prevention tester. (See Appendix, form H). This form, once completed, shall be submitted to the county no later than 30 days from the inspection date. Failure to do so may result in discontinuance of water service. 
(c)  Every person required to have a backflow prevention device shall have it inspected at least once each year by an approved backflow prevention device tester who will file his report on the inspection with the county within ten days following the inspection. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-8) 
Sec. 22-133. - Noncompliance; penalty for violation of division; abatement. 
(a)  Service of water to any premises shall be disconnected by the county when the installation of a backflow prevention device, as required by this division or other rules or regulations of the county, is not installed, tested and maintained. If it is found that a backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if unprotected cross connections exist on the premises and there is inadequate backflow protection at the service connection, water service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. All turnoff and turn-on service charges shall be paid by the consumer. 
(b)  Whenever the cross connection control coordinator determines that there has been a violation of this division, he shall notify the owner in writing of such violation and within 30 days the owner will submit a plan for correcting the violation. 
(c)  The chairman of the board of commissioners may cite the owner to the county magistrate's court for a violation of any provision of this division. Such violation shall be construed as an offense against the county and punishable by a fine not to exceed $300.00, imprisonment not to exceed 30 days, or both. 
(d)  The chairman of the board of commissioners may, in the name of the county, file in the county superior court a suit seeking the issuance of an injunction, damages, or other appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this division or other applicable law or regulation. Suit may be brought to recover any and all damages suffered by the county as a result of any action or inaction of any customer of the water system or other person who causes or suffers damage to the water system of the county due to a violation of this division. Suit may be filed by the county against any customer of the water system or owner for any expenses, loss, or damages of any kind or nature suffered by the county as the result of a violation of this division. 
(e)  The chairman of the board of commissioners may issue a show cause notice to any customer or owner directing him to appear before the chairman of the board of commissioners at a specified date and time to show cause why water service should not be discontinued for a violation of this division. The customer or owner may present his defense at such hearing. The notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the customer or owner or delivered personally to him at least ten days prior to the hearing date. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-9) 
Sec. 22-134. - Appendix. 
The appendix and forms referred to in this division are incorporated by reference and made a part of this division. A copy of such appendix is on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 7-8-85, § 10-11) 
Chapter 26 - BUSINESSES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1—26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANNUAL BUSINESS REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq. 

Sec. 26-26. - Business registration required for businesses operating in Tift County, Georgia. 
(a)  For 2003 and succeeding years, each person or entity engaged in any business, or who is a practitioner of a profession or occupation in the unincorporated area of Tift County, Georgia (hereinafter "county"), whether maintaining a location or office in the county or, in the case of a business with no location in the county, exerting substantial efforts and conducting significant business within the county shall register annually with and obtain a county business license from the Tift County Code Administration Director (hereafter "director") or his/her designee at the county office of code enforcement on or before July 1 of each year and such license shall be conspicuously displayed in the business location in Tift County. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in Tift County, such business registration shall be displayed to the director or his/her designees or to any law enforcement officer of Tift County upon request and shall be conspicuously displayed on any mobile business unit. 
(b)  Upon registration, the director shall as soon as practicable inspect such registrant's business location or job sites, and perform a reasonable investigation of such registrant's business activities to insure that such activities comply with all applicable state or local building, health, or safety codes; to determine whether such registrant has in effect any and all required insurance coverage, and any required state or federal licenses or permits; that the registrant has complied with section 26-30 herein; and to determine whether such registrant's business, trade, profession or occupation poses any threat to the safety, welfare, or public health of the citizens of Tift County. Inspection need not be completed prior to issuance of a county business license, but such license is subject to suspension if upon inspection the director finds the registrant has not complied with any and all applicable local, state and or federal ordinances, regulations, and laws or has failed to pay the regulatory fees required under subsection (c) below. 
(c)  Upon registering, each registrant shall pay an annual regulatory fee in the amount of $45.00 to defray the costs of inspections contemplated at subsection (b) above. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-27. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term "Tift County" or "county" is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean Tift County, Georgia. 
(b)  As used in this article, the term: 
(1)  Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. A renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession or occupation at such site. 
(2)  Person shall be held to include individuals, sole proprietors, corporations, LLCs, LLPs, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization or entity, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations. 
(3)  Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business registers, pays the regulatory fee, and obtains the county business license. 
(4)  Tift County Code Administration Department (the "department")is the agency charged with enforcement of this article. 
(5)  Tift County Code Administration Director (the "director") is the director of the code administration department and the person charged with enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-28. - Administrative fee structure; business registration tax structure. 
(a)  A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of $20.00 shall be required on all business registration tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. 
(b)  The business registration tax for persons in occupations and professions is as follows: 
0 to 5 employees ..... $50.00 
6 to 9 employees ..... 75.00 
10 or more ..... 150.00 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03) 
Sec. 26-29. - Businesses and trades prohibited. 
The following businesses and trades are prohibited in unincorporated areas of Tift County: 
(a)  Punch boards, or ticket games of chance, except those licensed by or conducted by the State of Georgia; 
(b)  Games of chance, except those licensed or conducted by the State of Georgia; and 
(c)  Fireworks and pyrotechnics (this section shall not be construed to prevent firework displays). 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-30. - Specific requirements for certain licenses. 
(a)  Air conditioning and heating, installation and service: State license is required before a county license may be issued. 
(b)  Bonding company: Must be approved by sheriff before license is issued. 
(c)  Cafe, restaurant, cafeteria: Must have approval from all appropriate regulating agencies before license is issued. 
(d)  Delicatessen, meat market, meat processor: Must have permit from health department before license is issued. 
(e)  Detective agency: State license is required and must also be approved by sheriff. 
(f)  Electrician: State license is required before a license is issued. Obtain permit prior to engaging in any work in Tift County. 
(g)  Exterminators: Permit is required from state department of entomology before a license is issued. 
(h)  Gas fitters and plumbers: State license is required before license is issued. Must also provide bond as set by board of commissioners and obtain permit prior to engaging in any work in Tift County. 
(i)  Junk dealer: Such person or persons shall hold their shop subject to visitation and inspection by the sheriff or his deputies and, upon refusal of inspection, his or her shop shall immediately be closed by the sheriff and the license forfeited. Minors shall have written permits from parents or guardians before selling to dealers. Purchase of any material from minor without written permit from parents shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(j)  Kennels (dog): Must be in area zoned for such business. 
(k)  Massage therapist: Must show certification. 
(l)  Pawnbrokers: Each person or firm engaged in the business of a pawnbroker or conducting or operating a pawnshop in unincorporated Tift County shall make a report to the sheriff of Tift County before 10:00 a.m. each day (except Sunday, when transactions for Saturdays shall be made the following Monday) of every article or item pawned to or purchased by him or her for the day and night previous. Said report shall specify the article or thing giving a full description thereof such as a number, mark, and all other details as will make identification of such articles clear and positive. Person or persons operating a pawnshop or engaged in the business of a pawnbroker shall hold their shops open to visitation and inspection by the sheriff or his deputies. Failure or refusal of any such pawnbroker or person or persons operating such pawnshop to submit to such visitation or inspection of such shop shall result in immediate closing of the shop by the sheriff. All licenses issued to pawnbrokers are subject to these provisions, and violations shall be punished by revocation and as provided for violation of this article. 
(m)  Precious metals dealer: Must be approved by the sheriff. 
(n)  Sales, closing out, quitting business, going out of business: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person, firm, partnership, or corporation to sell, offer or expose for sale, or to include in such inventory for sale any goods, wares, or merchandise which are not an actual part of the original stock of goods of the applicant. It shall further be unlawful for any person to hold or conduct a "Closing Out Sale," "Going Out of Business Sale" or a sale that is designated in any manner by which it is represented that the business of such person is being terminated unless such business is in fact terminated at the end of such sale; provided, that any such sale shall not last for more than 60 consecutive calendar days. The board of commissioners may, upon request of the business owner, grant an additional 30 days for such sale upon evidence that such extension is necessary; provided, however, that only one such extension may be granted. These provisions shall not apply to trustees in bankruptcy, executors or administrators of estates, receivers or public officials acting under judicial process. 
(o)  Taxicabs, transportation, nonemergency: Before issuance of any license, applicant must have proof of insurance coverage, property damage and personal liability for a minimum of $50,000.00 and deposit a copy of such policies with the code administration director or his designee covering each and every vehicle used in such taxicab/nonemergency transportation business. Each taxicab shall frame and display license in view of passengers at all times. 
(p)  Tree surgery: In addition to business license, must also have proof of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of $50,000.00 for bodily injury and $100,000.00 property damage indemnifying Tift County and any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such activities. 
(q)  Trenching and pipe laying: In addition to business license, must also obtain permit and post bond as set by the board of commissioners prior to engaging in any work within the county's right-of-way. 
(r)  Commercial and residential building contractors: Must verify current Tift County contractor's license and must obtain liability insurance coverage of at least $100,000.00 and workers compensation as required by Georgia law and provide proof thereof before the issuance of license. 
(s)  Any business not specifically identified above but required to be licensed by the state shall present such license. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-31. - Paying business registration tax on business with no location in Georgia. 
Registration and assessment of a business registration tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the State of Georgia if the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the county for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the county. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03) 
Sec. 26-32. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. 
The business registration of each business operated in the county's jurisdiction shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the director and that line of business being noted by the department upon the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-33. - The number of businesses considered to be operating in Tift County. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of business registration. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-34. - More than one place or line of business. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, said business will pay the regulatory fee only once. 
(Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-35. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the State of Georgia, a municipality or county of the State of Georgia, instrumentalities of the United States, the State of Georgia, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to register nor be subject to inspection and investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-36. - Effect of transacting business without registering and/or paying regulatory fee. 
(a)  Said regulatory fee shall be payable upon registration and no later than July 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by August 31 of such year, be subject to penalties for delinquency in the amount of ten percent of said fee per month. On any new professions, trade, or calling begun in Tift County on or after July 1 of each year the registration and payment of the regulatory fee shall be delinquent if not obtained within 60 days following commencement of the business. The registration herein provided for shall be issued by the Director and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said fee becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in Tift County, any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without first registering, paying the regulatory fee and obtaining a county business license such offender shall, upon conviction in the Tift County Magistrate Court, be punished as provided for herein. 
(b)  In addition to the above remedies, the director and/or the sheriff may proceed to collect the regulatory fee in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-37. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensing before the county business license may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-38. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a county business license, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-39. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
All persons subject to pay the regulatory fee pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary license for said business as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to register, obtain a county business license or pay the regulatory fee. Every person commencing business or the practice of a profession or occupation in Tift County after July 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the license herein provided for within 30 days following commencement of the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation within Tift County without first having so obtained said license, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. Said penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties, civil and criminal, herein provided and may be collected by the remedies herein provided for the collection of the regulatory fee, and shall have the same lien and priority as the regulatory fee to which the penalty is applied. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-40. - When registration required and regulatory fee due and payable; effect of transacting business when regulatory fee delinquent. 
(a)  Registration as herein required shall be for the fiscal year in which the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. There is hereby imposed a penalty upon each business or entity which fails to apply for and obtain an appropriate business license and pay all regulatory fees as provided herein before commencing such business. Any person transacting or offering to transact in Tift County any business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having obtained said registration shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. Said penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties, civil and criminal, herein provided; and may be collected by the remedies herein provided for collection of the regulatory fees, and shall have the same lien and priority as the regulatory fee to which the penalty is applied. 
(b)  The registration herein provided for shall be with and the license issued by the director, and if any persons, firm, corporation or other entity whose duty it is to register and obtain a license shall, after such license becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation in Tift County without first having obtained said license, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-41. - Penalty for article violation. 
Any person failing to register, pay the regulatory fee, or obtain a county business license or violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction before the magistrate court of Tift County, be fined in an amount not exceeding $1,000.00 and upon conviction any business operated by the convicted person shall shut down until such time as a business is registered and a license obtained and all regulatory fees due and payable have been received by the county. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-42. - Licensing director: authority to refuse license. 
The department shall have the authority to refuse to grant a license to an applicant or to revoke the license of a person or entity licensed by the Department upon a finding that the licensee or applicant has: 
(a)  Knowingly made misleading, deceptive, untrue, or fraudulent representations in the practice of a business or profession licensed under this article on any document submitted in connection therewith; or practiced fraud or deceit or intentionally made any false statement in obtaining a license to practice the licensed business or profession; or made a false or deceptive statement in connection with registration with the department; or 
(b)  Engaged in any fraudulent or deceptive conduct or practice harmful to the public or of a nature likely to jeopardize the interest of the public, including but not limited to business practices which result in the conveyance to the licensee or any person or entity affiliated with licensee a lien or security interest in the home of a resident of Tift County without such resident's knowledge and consent after full disclosure. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-43. - Businesses not subject to pay the regulatory fee required by this article. 
The following businesses, and practitioners of professions, and/or occupations are not subject to pay the regulatory fee required by this article, but are required to register with the department: 
(1)  Any state or local authority; 
(2)  Any nonprofit organization; 
(3)  Any vendor operating under a contract with a tax-exempt agricultural fair, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 2-2-8; 
(4)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agribusiness; 
(5)  Architects; 
(6)  Chiropractors; 
(7)  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers; 
(8)  Dealers of motor vehicles, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 10-1-622(1); 
(9)  Dentists; 
(10)  Embalmers; 
(11)  Funeral directors; 
(12)  Land surveyors; 
(13)  Landscape architects; 
(14)  Lawyers; 
(15)  Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors; 
(16)  Merchants or dealers as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-354 as to their deliveries to businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations in areas zoned for commercial use; 
(17)  Optometrists; 
(18)  Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 34; 
(19)  Owners or operators of bona fide coin operated amusement machines as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1, and owners or operators of businesses where bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, provided that such amusement machines have affixed current stickers showing payment of annual permit fees, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-9; 
(20)  Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 34; 
(21)  Podiatrists; 
(22)  Practitioners of physiotherapy; 
(23)  Psychologists; 
(24)  Public accountants; 
(25)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; 
(26)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. title 46, chapter 3; and 
(27)  Veterinarians. 
(28)  Any other business, profession, or occupation for which state licensure or registration is required by state law, unless the state law regulating such business or profession, or occupation specifically allows for regulation by local governments. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-44. - Examples of businesses, practitioners of professions, and occupations required to pay the regulatory fee created by this article. 
Examples of businesses or practitioners of professions or occupations which are subject to regulatory fees as defined in this article include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Autos and motorcycle racing; 
(2)  Boarding houses; 
(3)  Boxing and wrestling promotions; 
(4)  Building and construction contractors, subcontractors and workers; 
(5)  Burglar and fire alarm installers; 
(6)  Businesses which provide appearance bonds; 
(7)  Carnivals; 
(8)  Dealers in precious metals; 
(9)  Door-to-door salespersons and solicitations; 
(10)  Escort services; 
(11)  Firearm dealers; 
(12)  Flea markets (including persons who have more than three yard sales per year at the same location); 
(13)  Food service establishments; 
(14)  Fortunetellers; 
(15)  Garbage collectors; 
(16)  Handwriting analysis; 
(17)  Health clubs, spas and gyms; 
(18)  Hotels and motels; 
(19)  Hypnotists; 
(20)  Landfills; 
(21)  Locksmiths; 
(22)  Massage parlors; 
(23)  Modeling agencies; 
(24)  Newspaper vending boxes; 
(25)  Nursing and personal care homes; 
(26)  Parking lots; 
(27)  Pawnbrokers; 
(28)  Peddlers; 
(29)  Scrap metal processors; 
(30)  Shooting galleries and firearm ranges; 
(31)  Stables; 
(32)  Taxicab and limousine operators; 
(33)  Tattoo artists. 
(Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-45. - When regulatory fee due and payable. 
The regulation fee shall be payable to Tift County at the office of the director, on July 1 each year and delinquent if not paid on or before August 31 each year. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-46. - Amendment, repeal of provision. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the Board of Commissioners to assess and collect the regulatory fee provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-47. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any regulatory fee or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such regulatory fee, or failure to comply with any other provisions thereof, shall continue and remain in force until such regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-48. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the director and the Tift County Sheriff's Department to see that the provision of this article relating to registration, inspection, investigation and payment of regulatory fees are carried out; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the magistrate court of Tift County. It is hereby made the further duty of the director, sheriff, members of the sheriff's department, and their assistants to inspect all registrations issued by the county, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-49. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the board of commissioners of Tift County. All provisions hereto relating to any form of regulatory fee herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such regulatory fees have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-50. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-50.1. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not to be held invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent of the board of commissioners of Tift County that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, § 26-51, 3-8-04) 
Sec. 26-50.2. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 5-12-03; Ord. No. 2003-04, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 2004-01, § 26-52, 3-8-04) 
ARTICLE III. - SECONDHAND GOODS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Junk or metal dealers records, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-350 et seq.; duties of purchasers of gold bullion, gold dust, etc., O.C.G.A. § 12-4-120 et seq.; control of junkyards, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-240 et seq.; purchase and resale of used motor vehicles and used parts, O.C.G.A. § 40-4-40 et seq.; junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.; dealers in precious metals and gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-1 et seq.; Used Motor Vehicle Dismantlers, Rebuilders and Salvage Dealers Registration Act, O.C.G.A. § 43-48-1 et seq.; dealers in used watches, O.C.G.A. § 43-49-1 et seq.; pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq. 

Sec. 26-51. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  This article shall be applicable to all stores, swap shops, pawnshops, and businesses dealing, buying, selling, swapping, and any form of pawning of used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils, firearms, gold, silver, coins, precious metals, jewelry and precious stones, whether such sales, trades, purchases and swaps are retail, wholesale, or by any pawning in the unincorporated areas of the county. Specifically excluded are businesses dealing in buying or selling new merchandise. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in business are not covered by the terms of this article. 
(b)  This article is applicable to any business, person, association, partnership or corporation who shall engage in the business of selling, purchasing, exchanging, swapping or pawning of used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils, firearms, gold, silver, coins, precious metals, jewelry and precious stones within the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), §§ 1, 3; Mo. of 2-9-89) 
Sec. 26-52. - Enforcement of article. 
The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this article, and all procedures for enforcement of such article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate's court by the county sheriff, any county deputy sheriff, the chairman of the board of commissioners or a designated representative of the chairman of the board of commissioners and shall be prosecuted through that court. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), § 7) 
Sec. 26-53. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person convicted of violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), § 6) 
Sec. 26-54. - Engaging in business affected with public interest. 
Engaging in the business of buying, selling, swapping or pawning used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils, firearms, gold, silver, coins, precious metals, jewelry and precious stones within the unincorporated areas of the county is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest due to the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), § 2; Mo. of 2-9-89) 
Sec. 26-55. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any business to receive in pawn, trade or to buy from minors used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils, firearms, gold, silver, coins, precious metals, jewelry and precious stones. A minor, for the purpose of this article, is any individual who has not reached the age of 18 years. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), § 4) 
Sec. 26-56. - Regulations pertaining to buying and pawning of merchandise; receiving merchandise in swaps; reports of purchases. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any business covered by this article to buy, receive in pawn or receive in a swap any used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils, firearms, gold, silver, coins, precious metals, jewelry and precious stones, without complying with the following regulations: 
(1)  At the time of the sale, pawn or swap there shall be obtained from the seller, on a written form which the seller must sign, the following information: seller's name, residence address, date of birth, place of employment and identification of the item sold which will include the kind, serial number and manufacturer of the item. 
(2)  The information set out in subsection (1) of this section shall be placed upon a written form which the seller shall sign, and this information shall be made in duplicate on this form. Below the signature of the seller the name of the business and the location shall be shown, along with the date and hour of the transaction. Following this, the manager or person in charge of the business shall sign his name. 
(3)  The forms set forth in subsection (2) of this section shall be provided by the county sheriff's department to the business. The original signed form showing the information called for in subsection (2) of this section shall be delivered by the business to the county sheriff's department on the following day after the transaction is completed. Such delivery shall be made by hand or by placing the original in the U.S. mail, addressed to the county sheriff's department with adequate postage thereon. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person, business, association, partnership or corporation, pawnshop or firm required by subsection (1) of this section to fail to obtain the information required in subsection (1) of this section or fail to provide such information to the county sheriff's department as required by subsection (3) of this section. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person selling, pawning or swapping as set forth in subsection (1) of this section to give false information to the seller or to answer falsely any of the information required in subsection (1) of this section. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(1), § 5; Mo. of 2-9-89) 
Secs. 26-57—26-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; exception from local peddler or itinerant vendor licensing requirements for persons selling agricultural products, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6. 

Sec. 26-76. - Applicability of article. 
This article shall be applicable to all traveling and itinerant dealers; salesmen; and buyers of gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals of any kind or description, whether such sales, trades and purchases are retail, wholesale or by any form of pawn. Specifically excluded are wholesalers, buyers and sellers who sell, trade and deal only with mercantile establishments located in the unincorporated areas of the county. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in business are not covered by the terms of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 1) 
Sec. 26-77. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Itinerant or traveling dealer, salesman or buyer means a person, association, partnership or corporation which does not have a business license in the county and who shall engage in the business of purchasing, trading, or otherwise dealing in gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals of any kind or description, from members of the general public within the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-78. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, in the county magistrate court, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 12) 
Sec. 26-79. - Engaging in business affected with public interest. 
Engaging in the business of buying or dealing gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals by a traveling or itinerant dealer, salesman or buyer within the unincorporated limits of the county is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest because of the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 3) 
Sec. 26-80. - License—Registration required before issuance. 
(a)  All applicants for a business license under the provisions of this article shall, at least 72 hours prior to the time the applicant desires the business license, register with the county sheriff on a form to be provided by the sheriff. All applicants for registration and license shall furnish, in addition to such other information as the sheriff shall require, the following information to be written and signed on the registration form: 
(1)  Complete name of the person, corporation, partnership or association and its address. 
(2)  The name of the person who will conduct the business in the county and his local address. 
(3)  The location of the business in the unincorporated area of the county and the hours that such business will operate. 
(4)  The length of time the business is to be conducted, including the dates of opening and closing. 
(b)  It is hereby declared to be unlawful and a violation of this article for any itinerant or traveling dealer, salesman or buyer to engage in the buying, selling, trading or otherwise dealing in gold, silver, jewelry, coins or other precious metals within the unincorporated areas of the county without first complying with the registration set forth in subsection (a) of this section, other provisions of this article, and obtaining a license as provided in this section. 
(c)  No person shall engage in the business or activity regulated by this article or shall be a member of a partnership, association or an officer, stockholder or director in a corporation engaged in such business or activity, who shall have been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(d)  Within 72 hours after the registration as provided for in this section, the sheriff shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed business operation. If, upon investigation, the sheriff shall find that the applicant is of good moral character and has never been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and has met all the requirements of this article, he shall approve the issuance of a business license to the applicant. Upon approval by the sheriff and upon payment of a license tax to the county as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, a license shall be issued to the applicant. It shall be the duty of the county sheriff's department to enforce this article. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 4) 
Sec. 26-81. - Same—Licensee required to keep records. 
Every licensee under the provisions of this article shall keep a register upon which the licensee shall record the name, address, weight and height, social security number, driver's license number, a brief description of the person, or other identification of every person who buys, sells, trades for, or otherwise disposes of gold, silver, jewelry, coins or other precious metals, together with the date and time of the transaction, the amount paid or advanced, a full description of each article or item including the kind, style, material, color, make, all identifying names, numbers or marks. Such entry shall be made at the time the transaction occurs. Prior to dealing with a person the licensee shall require positive identification, either from a driver's license, social security card or other identifying document. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 5) 
Sec. 26-82. - Same—Revocation or suspension. 
Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the chairman of the board of commissioners upon recommendation by the sheriff for the violation of or the failure to comply with any provision of this article or for the violation of any law of the state, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given the licensee. The chairman of the board of commissioners shall immediately notify any licensee of any suspension or revocation of his license. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 11) 
Sec. 26-83. - Report to sheriff; contents; submission. 
Every licensee shall file daily written reports with the county sheriff by 10:00 a.m. on each business day, setting forth the transactions of the preceding business day and give on the report or reports the information set forth in section 26-81. It is hereby made the duty of the sheriff to obtain such reports promptly each business day. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 6) 
Sec. 26-84. - Selling, melting or disposing of articles. 
No gold, silver, jewelry, coins or other precious metals shall be sold, melted, altered or disposed of by any licensee until five days have elapsed from the time the sheriff has been given the report in which such articles or items are entered, and such articles or items shall not be transferred from within the county during the five-day period of time. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 7) 
Sec. 26-85. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any licensee to receive in pawn, trade or to buy from minors or to sell to minors goods, metals or articles of any character or description. A minor, for the purpose of this article, is an individual who has not reached the age of 18. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 8) 
Sec. 26-86. - Prohibited items; exemptions. 
No licensee shall take in pawn, receive, sell, trade or exchange any of the following articles: Shotgun or rifle with a barrel length of less than 18 inches, knucks, dirk, sword cane, blackjack, Bowie knife, spring-back knife, switchblade knife, or any knife with a blade exceeding four inches in length. It is not the intention of this section to prohibit case knives, butcher knives or other knives customarily used for domestic or industrial purposes only, nor shall any licensee own or keep on hand any of the weapons named or referred to in this section. 
(Ord. of 5-2-88, § 9) 
Secs. 26-87—26-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DOOR-TO-DOOR SOLICITORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-370 et seq.; Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-111. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chairman means the chairman of the board of commissioners. 
Clerk means the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
Company means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit. 
Door-to-door salesperson means the same as house-to-house salesperson. 
House-to-house salesperson means any person who solicits from residences without first making an appointment. 
Sheriff means the duly elected sheriff of the county or a duly appointed deputy acting in his stead. 
Solicitors means the same as house-to-house salesperson. 
Unincorporated areas means the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-112. - Enforcement of article. 
The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this article and all procedures for enforcement of such article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate's court by the chairman of the board of commissioners or a designated representative of the chairman and shall be prosecuted through that court. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 6) 
Sec. 26-113. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person convicted of violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 5) 
Sec. 26-114. - Registration. 
All applicants for a solicitation permit under the provisions of this article shall, at least 72 hours prior to the time the applicant desires the permit, register with the clerk on a form to be provided by the clerk. All applicants for permits shall furnish, in addition to such other information as the clerk shall require, the following information to be written, signed and attested to on the registration form: 
(1)  Complete name of the person or company and its permanent address. 
(2)  Phone number of the permanent office of the person or company. 
(3)  The name, permanent address and social security number of the person who will be in charge of conducting the solicitation. 
(4)  The name and address and signature of each salesperson who will be working in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(5)  A photograph of the person in charge and each salesperson. If the company cannot furnish photographs, they will be made by the county. 
(6)  List of merchandise to be sold and price list of same. 
(7)  Name and permanent address of all officers of the company. 
(8)  A list of where each salesperson is living while working in the county. 
(9)  The dates on which the solicitation shall take place. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 2) 
Sec. 26-115. - Regulations. 
(a)  No salesperson shall call on any residence after dark unless an appointment has been made previously. 
(b)  Any salesperson who is asked to leave a residence or premises shall immediately vacate the residence or premises. 
(c)  A salesperson shall not represent that the permit issued by the county is in any way an endorsement of the company. 
(d)  A copy of each permit shall be filed with the sheriff. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 3) 
Sec. 26-116. - Permits. 
After a company has complied with section 26-114, a permit for solicitation, signed by the chairman, shall be issued, allowing solicitations on the dates listed in section 26-114(9) in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 6-12-89, § 4) 
Secs. 26-117—26-140. - Reserved.

Sec. 26-141. - Prohibited acts.

Chapter 30 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; roads and bridges, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 110; zoning, app. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Provisions saved from repeal. 
The ordinance of November 29, 1979, authorizing the construction, maintenance and operation of a cable television system, together with the franchise agreement granted pursuant to such ordinance including all transfers and assignments, are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect. Official copies of such ordinance and franchise are on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
Secs. 30-2—30-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BASIC SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 30-36. - County to follow FCC rate regulations. 
The county will follow the FCC rate regulations in its regulation of the basic service rates and charges of the company and any other cable television system operating in the county, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions in the franchise. 
(Res. of 9-13-93, § 1) 
Sec. 30-37. - Consideration of views of interested parties. 
In connection with such regulation, the county will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties. 
(Res. of 9-13-93, § 2) 
Sec. 30-38. - Execution and filing of certification forms or other instruments. 
The county administrator is authorized to execute on behalf of the county and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC rate regulations in order to enable the county to regulate basic service rates and charges. 
(Res. of 9-13-93, § 3)
