ARTICLE II. - DISABLED PERSONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Handicapped person, O.C.G.A. § 30-1-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 70-16—70-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 

Sec. 70-26. - Purpose of article. 
This article shall be construed to protect the substantive rights of interested persons to meet appropriate due process standards, and to ensure that the county complies with the ACS and implementing regulations. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 8) 
Sec. 70-27. - Basis of procedure; complaints addressed to county clerk. 
(a)  The county has adopted an internal grievance procedure providing for prompt and equitable resolution of complaints alleging any action prohibited by the U.S. Department of Justice regulations implementing Title II of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA). Title II states, in part, that "…no otherwise qualified disabled individual shall, solely by reason of such disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination…" in programs or activities sponsored by a public entity. 
(b)  Complaints should be addressed to the county clerk, who has been designated to coordinate ADA compliance efforts. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2)) 
Sec. 70-28. - Form and content of complaint. 
A complaint should be filed in writing or verbally, contain the name and address of the person filing it, and briefly describe the alleged violation of the regulations. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 1) 
Sec. 70-29. - Filing deadline. 
A complaint should be filed within ten days after the complainant becomes aware of the alleged violation. Processing of the allegations of discrimination which occurred before this grievance procedure was in place will be considered on a case-by-case basis. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 2) 
Sec. 70-30. - Investigation. 
An investigation, as may be appropriate, shall follow a filing of complaint. The investigation shall be conducted by the county administrator. These rules contemplate informal but thorough investigations affording all interested persons and their representatives, if any, an opportunity to submit evidence relevant to a complaint. Under the Department of Justice regulations, the county need not process complaints from applicants for employment or from applicants for admission to post-secondary educational institutions. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 3) 
Sec. 70-31. - Issuance of determination as to validity; resolution. 
A written determination as to the validity of the complaint and a description of the resolution, if any, shall be issued by the county administrator and a copy forwarded to the complainant no later than 30 days after its filing. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 4) 
Sec. 70-32. - Maintenance of files and records. 
The ADA coordinator shall maintain the files and records of the county relating to the complaints filed. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 5) 
Sec. 70-33. - Request for reconsideration. 
The complainant can request a reconsideration of the case in instances where he or she is dissatisfied with the resolution. The request for reconsideration should be made within five days to the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 6) 
Sec. 70-34. - Pursuit of other remedies. 
The right of a person to a prompt and equitable resolution of the complaint filed under this article shall not be impaired by the person's pursuit of other remedies such as the filing of an ADA complaint with the responsible federal department or agency. Use of this grievance procedure is not a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies. 
(Res. of 10-7-92(2), § 7) 
Chapter 74 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; floods, ch. 62; health and sanitation, ch. 66; planning, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 98; taxation, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 110; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference— Registration and licensing of dealers, manufacturers and persons transporting mobile homes, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-38; removal of transportable housing from lands subject to writ of possession, O.C.G.A. § 44-7-59; ad valorem taxation of mobile homes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq.; issuance of mobile home location permits; display of decals, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492; the Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-130 et seq.; classification of mobile homes as a separate class of property for ad valorem property tax purposes, Ga. Const. art. VII, § I, ¶ III. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Installation of water service; owner/operator and county responsibilities. 
Mobile home park owners or operators who desire county water service are required to pay for installation of water service lines and meters to individual trailer spaces/lots, and the owner/operator is required to provide construction and maintenance easement, the dimensions to be determined by the county water superintendent. Materials will be ordered and construction scheduled upon receipt by the county of the full amount of the estimated installation costs. 
(Mo. of 3-14-94) 
Sec. 74-2. - Moving manufactured/mobile homes. 
(1)  Title. This section shall be known as and may be cited as the "Manufactured/Mobile Home Moving Ordinance." 
(2)  Definitions. 
(a)  Manufactured home means a new or used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which in the traveling mode, when erected on site, is 400 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling unit with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. Section 5401 et seq. For the purpose of the administration of this section, the term "manufactured home" shall not be interpreted to include mobile homes. For the purpose of this definition, "single-wide" shall be construed as any manufactured or mobile home having a width of between eight and 16 feet and is transported entirely in one section (Tift County Zoning Ordinance appendix A, section 2-16). 
(b)  Mobile home means a used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in a traveling mode when erected on site, is 400 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling unit with or without permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein. These were built prior to June 15, 1976, and do not meet current department of Housing and Urban Development Manufactured Home codes. Mobile homes manufactured prior to June 15, 1976, shall be prohibited in Tift County. Any mobile home manufactured prior to June 15, 1976, shall remain on the property it occupies. Any pre-1976 mobile home shall not move to another site without approval from the Tift County Zoning Board of Appeals (Tift County Zoning Ordinance appendix A, section 2-16A). 
(c)  Manufactured/mobile homes shall not be utilized for any purpose except a single family residence/dwelling. 
(d)  Dealer means a person, partnership, corporation individual who sells or offers for sale mobile homes. 
(e)  Locate or relocate a manufactured/mobile home means or includes the act of moving from one site to another a manufactured/mobile home. 
(3)  Permit and decal required. 
(a)  Before any person or dealer shall locate or relocate a mobile home within the unincorporated limits of Tift County, such person or dealer shall apply for and obtain from Tift County a permit and decal authorizing such location or relocation if such mobile home is intended to be used by the owner thereof as a residence for such person's self or as a residence for others or for any purpose other than resale. All persons engaged in moving or transporting a manufactured/mobile home, including owners, buyers, sellers, licensed dealers, haulers and any other person or entity moving or transporting a manufactured/mobile home regardless of origination or destination of the manufactured/mobile home shall be responsible for obtaining said permit and may be cited as provided herein for the failure to do so. 
(b)  The issuance of the permit referenced in subparagraph (a) above shall be evidenced by a decal which shall be prominently attached and displayed on the exterior of the manufactured/mobile home by the owner (Tift County Code of Ordinances section 74-35, amendment from August 14, 2006). 
(c)  A permit shall also be required authorizing the relocation of a manufactured/mobile home from Tift County to another county in Georgia or any other state after Tift County taxes have been paid. Tift County shall notify such other county of the date of issuance of such permit. 
(d)  Every person owning or operating a manufactured/mobile home park or dealership within Tift County or engaged in the business of renting lots upon which to place manufactured/mobile homes in Tift County shall furnish the Tift County Tax Assessor on the first day of each calendar year a complete list of all manufactured/mobile homes parked, rented, or otherwise located upon the property of the person making the return. 
(4)  Responsibility of utility company. No person supplying electricity, gas or water shall connect any electricity, gas or water into any manufactured/mobile home unless such home shall have been issued a permit as herein provided. 
(5)  Form; contents. Tift County Commissioners are hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe forms for such applications and for any permit issued pursuant thereto, as well as any other document required in connection with such application or permit, and authorized and empowered to require that applicants furnish information in writing as may be reasonably required to effectuate the purpose hereof. 
(6)  Permit fee. A fee set by Tift County Commissioners for the issuance of each permit shall be paid by the person or dealer who plans to locate or relocate a manufactured/mobile home. 
(7)  Penalty. 
(a)  Any person or dealer who does any act prohibited by this section or who fails to discharge any duty imposed hereby, shall be subject to the imposition of a fine of not more than $1,000.00 dollars, by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of time not to exceed 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, or up to the limits of any penalty provided by state law for the ordinance. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code or other ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
Maximum punishments which may be imposed for violations of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b). 
(8)  Implementation and enforcement. The duty of implementation and enforcement of this section rests with the Tift County Tax Assessor, Tift County Tax Commissioner, Tift County Sheriff, Tift County Code Enforcement or any other designee assigned by Tift County Commissioners or Tift County Manager who is hereby charged with the promulgation of sufficient procedures for ensuring compliance/enforcement with this section. Upon receiving information constituting probable cause made known to any person authorized to enforce the provisions of this section that a violation has occurred, a citation may be issued to the alleged violator requiring him or her to appear in Tift County Magistrate Court, on a day and time certain, to answer the charge or charges contained therein. 
(9)  Jurisdiction. The magistrates court of Tift County shall have jurisdiction over violations of this section and all procedures for enforcement of this section shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. tit. 15, ch. 10, art. 4. Complaints of violations of any provision of this section shall be brought before the magistrate's court on a citation issued by the authorized personnel of Tift County and shall be prosecuted through that court. Violations of this section will be tried upon citations either with or without a prosecuting attorney as determined by the Tift County Magistrate Judge. Service of citation shall be performed by authorized personnel of Tift County, Georgia. Citations shall meet all of the requirements as specified in the O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63, as amended. 
(Ord. of 1-1-10, §§ 1—9) 
Secs. 74-3—74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME LOCATION PERMITS 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dealer means a person, partnership, corporation, or individual who sells or offers for sale mobile homes. 
Mobile home means a movable or portable dwelling over 32 feet in length and over eight feet wide, constructed to be towed on its own chassis, connected to utilities and designed without a permanent foundation, which can consist of one or more components that can be retracted for towing purposes and subsequently expanded for additional capacity, or of two or more units separately towable, but designed to be joined into one integral unit. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-32. - Enforcing jurisdiction of article. 
The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violations of this article, and all procedures for enforcement of this article shall be as provided by O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate's court on a citation issued by the the chief tax assessor, any deputy tax assessor, and any officer of code enforcement, and shall be prosecuted through that court. Violations of this article will be tried upon citations either with or without a prosecuting attorney. Service of citation shall be performed by any of the authorities listed above. Citations shall meet all of the requirements as specified in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 9; Ord. of 8-11-08) 
Sec. 74-33. - Implementation and enforcement of article. 
The duty of implementation and enforcement of this article rests with the tax commissioner, who is hereby charged with the promulgation of sufficient procedures for ensuring compliance with this article. The tax commissioner is directed to implement procedures which will ensure that the citizens of the county will receive all procedural rights to which they are entitled under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 8) 
Sec. 74-34. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person or dealer who does any act prohibited by this article or who fails to discharge any duty imposed hereby, upon conviction, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 7) 
Sec. 74-35. - Permit and decal required. 
(a)  Before any person or dealer shall locate or relocate a mobile home within the unincorporated limits of Tift County, such person or dealer shall apply for and obtain from the tax commissioner a permit and decal authorizing such location or relocation if such mobile home is intended to be used by the owner thereof as a residence for such person's self, as a residence for others or for any purpose other than resale. 
(b)  The issuance of the permit referenced in subsection (a) above shall be evidenced by a decal which shall be prominently attached and displayed on the exterior of the mobile home by the owner. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 3; Mo. of 11-9-92; Ord. No. 2006-03, 8-14-06) 
Sec. 74-36. - Responsibility of utility company. 
No person supplying electricity, gas or water shall connect any electricity, gas or water into any mobile home unless such home shall have been issued a permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 4) 
Sec. 74-37. - Form; contents. 
The tax commissioner is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe forms for such applications and for any permit issued pursuant thereto, as well as any other document required in connection with such application or permit, and the tax commissioner is authorized and empowered to require that applicants furnish information in writing as may be reasonably required to effectuate the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 5) 
Sec. 74-38. - Fee. 
A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for the issuance of each permit shall be paid by the person or dealer who locates or relocates a mobile home. 
(Ord. of 5-14-90(1), § 6)

ARTICLE II. - LOITERING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36; ordinances proscribing loitering or related activities not preempted, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-24. 

Sec. 78-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved means adopted by the board of commissioners. 
County commissioners means the legally elected and qualified governing assembly of the county. 
Loitering means any conduct which constitutes a nuisance, a threat to morals or any interference with the rights of others. 
Right-of-way means all the property owned or maintained by the county upon which there is located a road, street, alley, land, sidewalk or path. 
Unincorporated areas means all areas of the county not included within the incorporated areas of a municipality. 
(Ord. of 3-2-87, § 2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-27. - Prohibited areas. 
No person shall loiter on the following public streets, rights-of-way and public property: 
(1)  All of the right-of-way of Pine Needle Place (County Road 307) from its intersection with the east right-of-way of Bowen Marchant Road eastward to the end of the right-of-way of Pine Needle Place including the cul-de-sac on the east end of Pine Needle Place. 
(2)  All of the right-of-way of Short Street from a point 300 feet west of its intersection with the centerline of Fourth Avenue eastward to a point 300 feet east of the intersection of Short Street with its intersection with the centerline of Fourth Avenue. 
(3)  All of the right-of-way of Fourth Avenue from a point 300 feet south of its intersection with the centerline of Short Street northward to a point 300 feet north of the centerline of Short Street. 
(Ord. of 3-2-87, § 3) 
Sec. 78-28. - Enforcement of article. 
The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this article and all procedures for enforcement of such article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate's court by the county sheriff, any deputy county sheriff, the chairman of the county commissioners or a designated representative of the chairman of the county commissioners and shall be prosecuted through that court. 
(Ord. of 3-2-87, § 5) 
Sec. 78-29. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person convicted of violating this article shall be subject to the imposition of punishment as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 3-2-87, § 4) 
Sec. 78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FALSE ALARMS 

Sec. 78-31. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "False Alarm Ordinance" of Tift County, Georgia. 
(Ord. of 2-10-97) 
Sec. 78-32. - Definitions. 
Alarm system. An assembly of equipment and devices designed and arranged to detect a fire or to signal an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or to signal an attempted robbery at a premises, and with respect to such signal public safety officers are expected to respond. 
False alarm. The activation of a fire, burglary, robbery or other similar alarm by an event other than a fire, burglary, or robbery on the premises. 
Person. The owner or lawful occupant of a residence, or any owner, partner, or manager of a business. 
Public safety officer. A law enforcement officer or a firefighter. 
Response. The dispatch of a public safety officer to the premises where an alarm system has been activated, indicating a fire, burglary, or robbery is in progress on the premises. 
(Ord. of 2-10-97) 
Sec. 78-33. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to activate an alarm system, otherwise cause an alarm system to be activated, or operate or maintain an alarm system which is activated at a time when no fire, burglary, or robbery is in progress at a premises but public safety officers are nevertheless dispatched to such premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to activate, otherwise cause to be activated, or operate or maintain any alarm system which automatically sends a prerecorded message or coded signal indicating the activation of an alarm system to any public safety agency. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey a cease and desist order issued pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Facilities owned or operated by the county or the county board of education are exempt from the prohibitions of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-10-97) 
Sec. 78-34. - Cease and desist orders. 
(a)  The sheriff of Tift County shall issue a cease and desist order to any person violating section 78-33(b) of this article. Such order shall direct that the alarm system in question be permanently disconnected immediately upon receipt of such order. 
(b)  The sheriff of Tift County shall also issue a cease and desist order to any person who has violated section 78-33(a) of this article six times within any calendar year. Such order shall direct that the alarm system in question be disconnected and shall not be reconnected until it has been inspected and serviced by a properly trained and licensed technician. Such order shall be rescinded upon receipt by the sheriff of written proof that such inspection and service have been performed and any malfunction or maladjustment corrected. 
(Ord. of 2-10-97) 
Sec. 78-35. - Penalties for false alarms. 
(a)  For the first three violations of section 78-33(a) at any premises in a calendar year, there shall be no penalty. 
(b)  For the fourth violation of section 78-33(a) at any premises, in a calendar year, there shall be a fine of $50.00. 
(c)  For the fifth violation of section 78-33(a) at any premises in a calendar year, there shall be a fine of $75.00. 
(d)  For the sixth and any subsequent violation of section 78-33(a) at any premises in a calendar year, there shall be a fine of $100.00. 
(e)  Any violation of a cease and desist order issued pursuant to this article shall be punished as provided for violation of a county ordinance, and shall be punishable, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(f)  Any failure or refusal to pay any fine provided for herein within 30 calendar days shall be punished as provided for violation of a county ordinance, and shall be punishable, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-11 for this Code. 
(Ord. of 2-10-97)

ARTICLE II. - DRUG-FREE WORKPLACE POLICY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Random drug testing of state employees in high-risk jobs, O.C.G.A. § 45-20-90 et seq.; Drug-Free Public Work Force Act of 1990, O.C.G.A. § 45-23-1 et seq. 

Sec. 82-31. - Enunciation. 
(a)  The United States Congress has recently enacted the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988. The purpose of this resolution is to ensure that work done under federal contracts or federal grants is performed in a drug-free work environment. 
(b)  In addition to prohibiting employees from engaging in the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession, or use of illegal drugs in the workplace, the county prohibits its employees from engaging in such illegal activity at all times and at all places. Such activity, even during nonworking hours, clearly affects an employee's ability to perform his public duties. Therefore, the county adopts the following as its drug-free policy: 
(1)  No employee of the county may illegally engage in the manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession, or use of a controlled substance at any time or place, including while at his workplace. Such unlawful activity will be considered a sufficient ground for a serious adverse personnel action, including dismissal from employment. 
(2)  If an employee is arrested for or convicted, including a plea of nolo contendere, of violating any criminal drug statute of any jurisdiction, regardless of whether the alleged violation occurred at the workplace or elsewhere, the employee must notify the board of commissioners' office in writing of each arrest or conviction as soon as possible, which must be within five calendar days of the arrest or conviction. 
(3)  Failure to comply with any part of this policy will result in serious adverse personnel action, including possible dismissal from employment. 
Any questions concerning this policy should be directed to the board of commissioners' office. 
(Res. of 9-14-89, §§ I—III) 
Sec. 82-32. - Drug testing required for applicants for employment. 
Drug testing for illegal drugs for final applicants for employment with the county is required. 
(Mo. of 3-12-90(2)) 
Sec. 82-33. - Provisions for drug-free workplace. 
The county will provide a drug-free workplace by doing the following: 
(1)  Publishing a statement notifying its employees that the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensing, possession or use of a controlled substance is prohibited in the contractor's workplace and specifying the actions that will be taken against employees for violations of such prohibition. 
(2)  Establishing a drug-free awareness program to inform its employees about: 
a.  The dangers of drug abuse in the workplace; 
b.  The agency/organization's policy of maintaining a drug-free workplace; 
c.  Any available drug counseling, rehabilitation and employee assistance programs; and 
d.  The penalties that may be imposed upon employees for drug abuse violations occurring in the workplace. 
(3)  Provide all employees engaged in performance of federally funded public transportation work with a copy of the statement required in subsection (1) of this section. 
(4)  Notify all employees in the statement required in subsection (1) of this section that the employee will: 
a.  Abide by the terms of the statement; and 
b.  Notify the employer of any criminal drug statute conviction for a violation occurring in the workplace no later than five days after such conviction. 
(5)  Notify the state department of transportation within ten days after receiving notice under subsection (4)b. of this section, from an employee or otherwise receiving actual notice of such conviction. Within 30 days after receiving notice under subsection (4) of this section of a conviction, imposing the following sanctions or remedial measures on any employee who is convicted of drug abuse in the workplace: 
a.  Taking appropriate personnel action against such employee up to and including termination; or 
b.  Requiring such employee to satisfactorily participate in a drug abuse assistance or rehabilitation program approved for such purposes by federal, state, or local health, law enforcement or other appropriate agency. 
(6)  Making a good faith effort to maintain a drug-free workplace through implementation of subsections (1)—(6) of this section. 
(Mo. of 4-10-89) 
Secs. 82-34—82-55. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - ZONING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; authority to adopt plans and exercise zoning powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 86-51—86-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC HEARINGS 

Sec. 86-66. - Hearing called. 
(a)  Notice; contents; publication. Before taking action on a proposed amendment, the board of commissioners shall hold a public hearing thereon. At least 15 but not more than 45 days' notice of the time, place, and purpose of the hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the county. Such notice shall also state the application number and date, and shall contain a summary of the proposed amendment, if a text amendment; and, in the case of a map amendment, the location of the property, its area, the name of the owner or their authorized agent, and the present and proposed zoning classification for the property affected. 
(b)  Disclosure by opponents of rezoning action. Further, such advertisement shall advise the public pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-3 that any opponent of a proposed rezoning action who has made campaign contributions aggregating $250.00 or more to a local government official of the local government which will consider the application within two years of the date of the application shall be required to file a disclosure with the governing authority of the respective local government showing: 
(1)  The name and official position of the local government official to whom campaign contributions were made; and 
(2)  The dollar amount and description of each campaign contribution made by the opponent to the local government official during the five years immediately preceding the filing of the application for the proposed rezoning action and the date of each contribution. 
Such disclosure shall be required to be filed at least five calendar days prior to the scheduled hearing. 
(Mo. of 5-10-93(1)(A)) 
Sec. 86-67. - Notice to interested parties. 
A notice shall be given to the applicant and the planning commission of the date, time, and place of the public hearing. All application files shall be placed in the custody of the zoning administrator and be open to public inspection during regular office hours. 
(Mo. of 5-10-93(1)(B)) 
Sec. 86-68. - Procedure. 
(a)  Placement on agenda; opening. All public hearings on zoning matters shall be placed on the board of commissioners' agenda under a section entitled public hearings. The board of commissioners' chairman, or his designee, shall officially declare the public hearing open and shall note that the county's written public hearing procedures, the county's standards for exercise of zoning powers, and a copy of the state's conflict of interest law are available to the attending public as a handout and are posted for public review. 
(b)  Announcement of matter for consideration; report of zoning administrator; public input procedures. The zoning administrator and/or designee shall then announce the matter for consideration. The chairman shall then call for acknowledgement of a potential conflict of interest by members of the board of commissioners. The zoning administrator will then report the staff recommendation and the recommendation of the Greater Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission. The chairman shall then allow public input. General procedures to be followed will require citizen comments to be heard in an orderly fashion. Citizens speaking in favor of the request shall be heard first, followed by those opposed to the issue. All speakers will be asked to provide his name and address for the public record. Citizens are requested to keep their comments as brief as possible so that all who wish to be heard will have adequate time. When there is a large number of citizens wishing to testify at a given hearing, the presiding officer may invoke reasonable time limitations on both the proponents and opponents of a request. In such cases, these time limits shall apply to both sides of an issue equally. Citizens shall address their comments to the board of commissioners as a whole. Individual attacks or cross examination of commission members, county employees or other citizens will be ruled out of order. The board of commissioners retains the privilege to ask any questions of staff or any citizen present for clarification. 
(c)  Closing of hearing; consideration by board; rendering of decision; approval, denial, tabling. After all citizen comments have been received, all further discussion of the specific application is reserved for the board of commissioners. The chairman shall then declare the public hearing closed, and no further public comment will be entertained. The board of commissioners will then render a decision on the application. Decisions may include approval, denial or tabling of the decision to a time, place and date specific. In the case of tabling of a matter, no further public comment will be entertained upon further consideration of the matter. 
(d)  Basis for decision to table issue. When, in the opinion of the board of commissioners, the official public hearing has brought forth substantial new evidence or testimony not available to the Greater Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission at the time of their review of a zoning matter, or should the board of commissioners desire to request further study by the planning and zoning commission of a particular aspect of an application, it shall be the policy of the board of commissioners to table the issue and request that the planning and zoning commission restudy the issue and affirm or amend its recommendation, which action shall be reported to the board of commissioners prior to making a final decision. Under no circumstances will public comment be entertained by the board of commissioners following the closing of the public hearing. 
(Mo. of 5-10-93(1)(C)) 
Secs. 86-69—86-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VIOLATION INVESTIGATION AND ENFORCEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Copies of the forms referred to in this division are available in the office of the zoning administrator. 

Sec. 86-81. - General procedure. 
(a)  Violations brought to zoning administrator. Alleged violations of the county zoning ordinance typically are brought to the attention of the zoning administrator by routine field inspections by various county code enforcement personnel or by citizens' complaints. 
(b)  Filling out of form no. 1; assignment of case number. Once a complaint about an alleged violation has been received, zoning staff will fill out an enforcement inspection report (form no. 1) and assign a case number. This report may require additional background work such as identification of property owners, specific property location and size, as well as zoning classification in order to determine specific limitations or requirements for particular properties mandated by the county zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Field inspection. Staff will then, as soon as possible, make a field inspection of the alleged violation. Photographs generally should be taken if an alleged violation is noted in order to document field observations. It is generally recommended that field inspections of alleged violations be conducted by two members of the zoning/codes enforcement staff so that inspection report findings can be collaborated in case a specific case might require judicial review or action. 
(d)  Time constraint. Staff will attempt to complete steps 1, 2, and 3 in a timely fashion, but generally, these steps can be accomplished in 15 working days. 
(Ord. of 9-9-91(1)) 
Sec. 86-82. - First contact (voluntary compliance). 
(a)  Form no. 2; abatement request. If a violation is noted, staff will attempt to make personal contact with the violator, noting the specific actions required to abate the violation. Staff will specify a 15-workday period to correct the violation. A letter (form no. 2) will be sent providing appropriate information and requesting abatement within 15 working days. Dates and requirements, as well as suspense deadlines, will be logged on form no. 1. This letter (form no. 2) will be sent certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(b)  Request by violator for extension. If a violator requests extension of time to abate the violation, a 15-workday extension will automatically be granted. 
(c)  Reinspection. Staff will utilize a suspense file, and upon contact by the alleged violator, or upon completion of the 15-day waiting period, staff will reinspect the premises for abatement of the violation. Should the inspection indicate that the violation has been abated, the case file will then be closed. 
(Ord. of 9-9-91(1)) 
Sec. 86-83. - Second contact (matter requiring involuntary compliance); notice of violation (form no. 3); enforcement (form no. 4). 
Staff will review the case file to date and prepare a certified letter, return receipt requested, notice of violation (form no. 3). This notice will, like the first notice, allow 15 working days for abatement, and a followup field inspection is required. If not utilized during first contact procedure, a 15-workday extension can be granted, upon request by alleged violator, to allow time to abate alleged violation. If the violation has been corrected, the case file will be closed. If not corrected, enforcement action punchlist (form no. 4) will be prepared, an informational copy given to the county administrator, and a full copy of the file forwarded to the county attorney for formal action. 
(Ord. of 9-9-91(1)) 
Sec. 86-84. - Stay of enforcement. 
Filing of an appeal to determination of zoning administrator to the zoning board of appeals or filing of an application for rezoning with the board of commissioners will automatically stay enforcement until the appeal or rezoning question is resolved. 
(Ord. of 9-9-91(1)) 
Chapter 90 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; cable communications, ch. 30; floods, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 94; subdivisions, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 110; zoning, app. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Installation of driveway pipe. 
Requirements for installation of driveway pipe for the purposes of providing access from private property to county roads are as follows: 
(1)  All driveway pipe will be furnished by the landowner. 
(2)  A county permit form can be picked up at the tax assessor's office or the county road department office. 
(3)  The county engineer or director of roads and public works will determine the size of driveway pipe needed. 
(4)  On state rights-of-way a DOT permit will be secured from the DOT by the landowner. The county will act as a contractor for the landowner and install the driveway pipe. The county will not do any paving or other maintenance work on the state rights-of-way. 
(5)  On county rights-of-way the county road department will install the driveway pipe furnished by the landowner at no additional cost to the landowner. 
(6)  There will be no headwalls on driveway pipe that extend above ground level. 
(Mo. of 3-12-90(1)) 
Sec. 90-2. - Provisions saved from repeal. 
The provisions regarding the naming of county roads, as set forth in a motion adopted August 9, 1993, are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the county. 
Secs. 90-3—90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET NUMBER DISPLAY 

Sec. 90-31. - Enforcement of article. 
The responsibility for making inspections to determine owner compliance with this article and for the enforcement of the provisions of this article shall rest upon the board of commissioners, county building official, county sheriff's department, and their designees and with officers authorized, directed and empowered to enforce all ordinances of the county. The agents and employees of such departments are hereby authorized and hereby empowered to make cases and issue citations for violations of this article. However, all public safety agencies providing services in the county are authorized to identify property owners in violation of this article and to forward notification of violations to the county building official for appropriate action. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 5) 
Sec. 90-32. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  Any person who violates or fails to comply upon direction with the provisions of this article as it now exists or as it may hereafter be amended, or who shall fail to do anything required by this article as it now exists or as it may hereafter be amended, is hereby declared to be in violation of this article. 
(b)  Each and every day that any such violation exists shall be deemed to be a separate offense under the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Any such violation, upon conviction, as prescribed by the laws of the state and this article, shall be punishable by fine or imprisonment or both, not to exceed 30 days' incarceration and/or a $500.00 fine for each and every separate violation of this article. 
(d)  The imposition of any such fine or imprisonment, or both, for any violation shall not excuse the violation nor permit it to continue, and all such violators shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within the time as prescribed by the court having jurisdiction of such matter, and in the absence of any such completion time being fixed by the court, within a reasonable time after such violations occur. 
(e)  The application of any fine, imprisonment, or other penalty shall not be construed to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions or to postpone any action required. 
(f)  The remedies set out in this section for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article shall not be deemed to be exclusive, but shall be cumulative of all other remedies, civil or criminal, provided by the laws of the state, or by the ordinances of the county. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 7) 
Sec. 90-33. - Required. 
Every house, mobile home, apartment, business, or other building having a street address number assigned to it under the system of numbering in the unincorporated county shall display such number in a readily visible manner and in compliance with the requirements of this article. Mobile home parks and apartment complexes, including duplex dwelling structures, shall also be required to have each individual pad, lot number or apartment number displayed in a readily visible manner and in compliance with the requirements of this article. Such lot, pad or apartment numbers shall be in sequence unless directional signs are provided for numbers not in sequence. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 1) 
Sec. 90-34. - Method. 
Street address numbers shall be prominently displayed in one or more of the following manners: 
(1)  Assigned street address numbers may be fixed to the house, apartment, business or other building itself, provided that such house, apartment, business or other building is not more than 50 feet from the curbline, pavement edge, or edge of travel way of the street in front of such building, and the number is readily visible from the street by persons traveling along the street in each direction. 
(2)  Street address numbers may also be placed on mailboxes or a sign located on the premises in front of the house, apartment, business or other building, provided that such sign is of a durable type, and is located not more than 50 feet from the curbline, pavement edge, or edge of travel way of the street in front of the property, and provided that the numbers on such sign shall be readily visible from the street by persons traveling along the street in each direction. 
(3)  On curbed streets, assigned street address numbers may be painted on the curb. It is recommended, but not required, that painting street address numbers permanently on curbs be done in addition to affixing such numbers to houses, mailboxes and signs as provided in this section. The responsibility for maintaining clearly legible street address numbers is placed on the property owner. 
(4)  If the house, apartment, business or other building to be numbered is more than 50 feet from the curb, pavement edge or edge of travel way of the street in front of the property, or if for any reason a street address number affixed to the building would not be readily visible from the street by persons traveling along the street in each direction, then the street address number shall be displayed on a sign or mailbox on the premises or clearly painted on the curb in front of such structure, complying with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 2) 
Sec. 90-35. - Size and condition of numbers. 
Street address numbers affixed to buildings or signs shall be a minimum of four inches in height. Those affixed to mailboxes in the manner specified in this article shall be a minimum of two inches in height. All such signs shall be of a color contrasting to the background so as to be clearly visible. Street address numbers and signs to which they are affixed shall be maintained at all times in good condition. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 3) 
Sec. 90-36. - Duty of owner; notification. 
The obligation of complying with the provisions of this article shall be upon the owner of the property. The property owner shall have 30 calendar days from the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives to comply with the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of such owner, upon affixing a number as provided by this article, to remove any incorrect previous numbers which might be mistaken for or confused with a number assigned to such structure by any governmental agency. Failure to comply within 30 days shall constitute a violation of this article. Upon such violation, notice shall be given the owner of the property or his agent specifying the particulars of the violation and requiring that such violation be brought into compliance with this article within ten calendar days after receipt of such notice. Failure to comply within the ten calendar days shall be punishable, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 4) 
Sec. 90-37. - Issuance of permits and final approvals for certificates of occupancy contingent upon compliance with article. 
No building permits shall be issued for any principal building until the owner or developer has procured from the building official for the county the official number of the premises. Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal building erected or repaired after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives shall be withheld until permanent and proper numbers have been displayed in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-13-95, § 6) 
Secs. 90-38—90-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENCROACHMENTS ON PUBLIC ROADS 

Sec. 90-66. - Requirements for encroachers. 
Any person, firm, company, sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, organization, individual, or government who desires to encroach and/or cross any public road in the unincorporated areas of the county, maintained by the county, shall be required to: 
(1)  Obtain and complete a permit from the county engineer. 
(2)  Repair the road to the specifications of the DOT and to the satisfaction of the county engineer. 
(3)  Call for an inspection by the county engineer during the repair process when the: 
a.  Road is cut. 
b.  Cut is backfilled. 
c.  Concrete is poured. 
d.  Job is completed. 
(4)  Make application for a permit at least 48 hours prior to the time the encroachment is to be made. 
(5)  Complete all repairs and submit completed job to the county engineer for inspection in not less than 14 days after the work is begun. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86, § I) 
Sec. 90-67. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person, firm, company, sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, organization, individual, or government who violates this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment not to exceed 60 days, or both. 
(Ord. of 4-7-86, § II) 
Editor's note— Application and permit forms for utility facility encroachments or other public road crossings are available in the office of the county engineer. 
Sec. 90-68. - Use of certain mailbox supports prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section for mailboxes to be mounted in such a manner as to present a serious threat of damage to vehicles or the motoring public in Tift County. For purposes of construction of this provision the use of the following materials and/or method in mounting mailboxes shall be prohibited: 
(1)  Heavy metal posts; 
(2)  Concrete posts; 
(3)  Brick bases; 
(4)  Supports filled with concrete; 
(5)  Mailbox supports fashioned of heavy farm equipment; 
(6)  Any method not approved by the postmaster general; and/or 
(7)  Other materials which threaten damage to vehicles and/or serious injury to vehicle occupants including but not limited to the following: 
a.  Material of a masonry nature; 
b.  Other material that would not readily yield upon impact; 
c.  Any material which could be classified by the state highway engineer as a hazardous fixed object; 
d.  Wood exceeding four inches × four inches or if round, more than four inches in diameter; 
e.  Hollow metal material more than three inches in diameter. 
The purpose of this section is to prevent utilization of mailbox supports which threaten injury to person or property. Mounting mailboxes with light metal and/or traditional wooden supports shall be appropriate. The purpose of this provision is to prevent utilization of mailbox supports which present a threat beyond that which is inherent and necessary in mounting mailboxes. 
(b)  The county engineer and/or building inspector shall be authorized to inquire as to how mailboxes will be mounted upon assigning a house number to the property and shall insure that a property owner is aware of the provision of this section. 
(c)  Should a property owner be determined to be in violation of this section, the county engineer and/or county building inspector shall issue a notice in writing to such property owner, which shall be given by certified mail, requesting that remedial action be taken within ten days from the date of such notice. Should the property owner fail to take remedial action following such notice, the county engineer, the building inspector and/or any employee of the county sheriff's department shall be authorized to seek enforcement of this section through the magistrate's court of the county. 
(d)  Penalties for violation of this section shall be as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96; Ord. of 12-9-96) 
Secs. 90-69—90-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-101. - Purpose. 
The purpose and intent of this article is to: 
(a)  Establish a local policy concerning telecommunications providers and services; 
(b)  Establish clear local guidelines, standards and nine frames for the exercise of local authority with respect to the regulation of telecommunications providers and services; 
(c)  Promote competition in telecommunications; 
(d)  Minimize unnecessary local regulation of telecommunications providers and services; 
(e)  Encourage the provision of advanced and competitive telecommunications services on the widest possible basis to businesses, institutions and residents of Tift County; 
(f)  Permit and manage reasonable access to the public ways of the county for telecommunications purposes on a competitively neutral basis; 
(g)  Conserve the limited physical capacity of the public ways held in public trust by the county; 
(h)  Assure that the county's current and ongoing costs of granting and regulating private access to and use of the public ways are fully paid by the persons seeking such access and causing such costs; 
(i)  Secure fair and reasonable compensation to the county and the residents of the county for permitting private use of the public ways; 
(j)  Assure that all telecommunications carriers providing facilities or services within the county comply with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the county; 
(k)  Assure that the county can continue to fairly and responsibly protect the public health, safety and welfare; 
(l)  Enable the county to discharge its public trust consistent with rapidly evolving federal and state regulatory policies, industry competition and technological development. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-102. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, and the interpretation and enforcement thereof, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless the context of the sentence in which they are used shall indicate otherwise: 
Affiliate means a person that (directly or indirectly) owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with another person. 
Alternative tower structure shall mean man-made trees, clock towers, bell steeples, light poles and similar alternative-design mountain structures that camouflage or conceal the presence of antennas or towers. 
Antenna shall mean any exterior apparatus designed for telephonic, radio, or television communications through the sending and/or receiving of electromagnetic waves. 
Annual gross reserve. (Reserved.) 
Cable act shall mean the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 USC Sec. 532, et seq., as now and hereafter amended. 
Cable operator means a telecommunications carrier providing or offering to provide "cable service" in unincorporated Tift County as that term is defined in the Cable Act. 
Cable service for the purpose of this article shall have the same meaning provided by the Cable Act. 
County means Tift County. 
County property means and includes all real property owned by the county, other than public streets and utility easements as those terms are defined herein, and all property held in a proprietary capacity by the county, which are not subject to right-of-way licensing and franchising as provided in this article. 
Excess capacity means the volume or capacity in any existing or future duct, conduit, manhole, handhole or other utility facility within the public way that is or will be available for use for additional telecommunications facilities. 
FCC or federal communications commission means the federal administrative agency, or lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee telecommunications carriers, services and providers on a national level. 
GDOT means the Georgia Department of Transportation. 
Governing authority means the board of commissioners of Tift County, Georgia. 
Height means, when referring to a tower or other structure, the distance measured from ground level to the highest point on the tower or other structure, even if said highest point is an antenna. 
Other ways means the highways, streets, alleys, utility easements or other rights-of-way in unincorporated Tift County, but under the jurisdiction and control of a governmental entity other than the county. 
Overhead facilities means utility poles, utility facilities and telecommunications facilities located above the surface of the ground, including the underground supports and foundations for such facilities. 
Person means and includes corporations, companies, associations, joint stock companies or associations, firms, partnerships, limited liability companies and individuals and includes their lessors, trustees and receivers. 
Preexisting towers and antennas means any tower or antenna for which a permit has been properly issued prior to the effective date of this article. Any such preexisting towers and antennas shall not be required to meet the requirements of this article, other than the requirements of the FAA, the FCC, and any other agency of the federal government with the authority to regulate towers and antennas, and the requirements of the Tift County building codes. 
PSC or public service commission means the state administrative agency, or lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee telecommunications carriers, services and providers in the State of Georgia. 
Public street means any highway, street, alley or other public right of way for motor vehicle traffic under the jurisdiction and control of the county which has been acquired, established, dedicated or devoted to highway purposes not inconsistent with telecommunications facilities. 
Public way means and includes all public streets and utility easements, as those terms are defined herein, now or hereafter owned by the county, but only to the extent of the county's right, title, interest or authority to grant a license or franchise to occupy and use such streets and easements for telecommunications facilities. 
Site means the actual area encompassed by the telecommunications tower or tall structure, including its guy wires or other supports. In the case of a stand-alone tower, site shall mean the tower and a radius of 300 feet around said tower. 
State means the State of Georgia. 
Surplus space means that portion of the usable space on a utility pole which has the necessary clearance from other pole users to allow its use by a telecommunications carrier for a pole attachment. 
Tall structure means any structure constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground, that is in excess of 35 feet in height. Among other things, tall structures include buildings, billboards, towers, and man made trees, but does not include walls or fences. 
Telecommunications carrier means and includes every person that directly or indirectly owns, controls, operates or manages plant, equipment or property in Tift County, used or to be used for the purposes of offering telecommunications service. 
Telecommunications provider means and includes every person who provides telecommunications service over telecommunications facilities without any ownership or management control of the facilities. 
Telecommunications facilities/services means the providing or offering for rent, sale or lease, or in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal of voice, data, image, graphic and video programming information between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar facilities, with or without benefit of any closed transmission medium. 
Telecommunications system. See "Telecommunications facilities/services." 
Tower means any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supporting lattice towers, guyed towers and monopoles but not alternative tower structures. The term includes radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common carrier towers, cellular telephone towers and the like, excluding amateur radio antennas. 
Underground facilities means utility and telecommunications facilities located under the surface of the ground, excluding the underground foundations or supports for overhead facilities. 
Usable space means the total distance between the top of a utility pole and the lowest possible attachment point that provides the minimum allowable vertical clearance. 
Utility easement means any easement owned by the county and acquired, established, dedicated or devoted for public utility purposes not inconsistent with telecommunications facilities. 
Utility facilities means the plant, equipment and property, including but not limited to the poles, pipes, mains, conduits, ducts, cables, wires, plant and equipment located under, on or above the surface of the ground within the public ways of the county and used or to be used for the purpose of providing utility or telecommunications services. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-103. - Registration. 
All telecommunications carriers and providers engaged in the business or transmitting, supplying or furnishing of telecommunications originating or terminating in the county shall register with the county pursuant to Division 2 of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-104. - Airport area restrictions. 
No telecommunications towers with a height above 35 feet shall be located within a three-mile radius of any public airport, unless granted special exception pursuant to the zoning regulations of Tift County. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-105. - Telecommunications license. 
Any telecommunications carriers who desire to construct, install, operate, maintain, or otherwise locate telecommunications facilities in, under, over or across any public way of the county for the sole purpose of providing telecommunications service to persons and areas outside the county shall first obtain a license granting the use of such public ways from the county pursuant to Division 3 of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-106. - Telecommunications franchise. 
Any telecommunications carriers who desire to construct, install, operate, maintain or otherwise locate telecommunications facilities in, under, over or across any public way of the county, and to also provide telecommunications services to persons or areas in unincorporated Tift County, shall first obtain a franchise granting the use of such public ways from the county pursuant to Division 4 of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-107. - Cable television franchise. 
Any telecommunications carrier who desires to construct, install, operate, maintain or locate telecommunications facilities in any public way of the county for the purpose of providing cable service to persons in the unincorporated areas of the county shall first obtain a cable franchise from the county as provided in Division 5 of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-108. - Application to existing franchise ordinances and agreements. 
This article shall have no effect on any existing franchise ordinance or franchise agreement until: 
(a)  The expiration of said franchise ordinance or agreement; 
(b)  An amendment to an unexpired franchise ordinance or franchise agreement, unless both parties agree to defer full compliance to a specific date not later than the present expiration date. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-109. - Application to existing telecommunications facilities and structures. 
This article shall not affect any telecommunications facilities and/or structures existing on June 15, 1997; provided, however, that telecommunications carriers and providers shall secure licenses and/or franchises provided herein, and shall provide the county with an accurate map or maps certifying the location of all telecommunications facilities within the public ways. At any time those facilities and/or structures be replaced, application for the new facilities/structures and payment of appropriate fees shall be required, but so long as the new or replacement facilities/structures are of reasonably similar design and height as the facilities/structures being replaced, no zoning action shall be required. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-110. - Distance requirements between towers and tall structures. 
An additional tower or tall structure shall be permitted on an existing tower site provided the new structure is of less stature and is less obtrusive than the existing structure, in the opinion of the county engineer, and provided further that the additional tower or tall structure is completely contained within the existing tower site, including supporting guy wires. Otherwise, minimum spacing between such towers and/or tall structures shall be 500 feet. Distance shall be measured by straight line from the base of each tower or tall structure. 
Communications towers/antenna which are accessory to a permitted use and comply with all other regulations for the district in which they are located may be mounted on but shall not extend more than 20 feet above an existing structure. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-111. - Penalties. 
Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of the Code of Tift County. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-112. - Other remedies. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting any judicial remedies that the county may have, at law or in equity, for enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-113. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or other portion of this article, or its application to any person, is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part by any court or agency of competent jurisdiction, said decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Secs. 90-114—90-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION OF CARRIERS AND PROVIDERS 

Sec. 90-121. - Registration required. 
All telecommunications carriers and providers that offer or provide any telecommunications service for a fee directly to the public, either in the unincorporated areas of the county, or outside the unincorporated areas of the county from telecommunications facilities in the unincorporated areas of the county, and whether said telecommunications facilities are located on public property or private property or a combination of public and private property, shall register with the county pursuant to this division on forms to be provided by the county clerk, which shall include the following: 
(a)  The identity and legal status of the registrant, including any affiliates. 
(b)  The name, address and telephone number of the officer, agent or employee responsible for the accuracy of the registration statement. 
(c)  A description of registrant's existing or proposed telecommunications facilities in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(d)  A description of the telecommunications service that the registrant intends to offer or provide, or is currently offering or providing, to persons, firms, businesses or institutions in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(e)  Information sufficient to determine whether the registrant is subject to public way licensing or franchising under this article. 
(f)  Information sufficient to determine whether the transmission, origination or receipt of the telecommunications services provided or to be provided by the registrant constitutes an occupation or privilege subject to any telecommunications tax, utility message tax or other occupation tax imposed by the county. 
(g)  Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for and received any certificate of authority required by the Georgia Public Service Commission or other applicable agency to provide services or facilities in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(h)  Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for and received any construction permit, operating license or other approvals required by the federal communications commission to provide telecommunications services or facilities in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(i)  Information sufficient to determine that the applicant is a member of the utility protection center. 
(j)  Such other information as the county may reasonably require. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-122. - Registration fee. 
Each application for registration as a telecommunications carrier or provider shall be accompanied by a fee of $25.00. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-123. - Purpose of registration. 
The purpose of registration under this division is to: 
(a)  Provide the county with accurate and current information concerning the telecommunications carriers and providers who offer or provide telecommunications services within the county, or that own or operate telecommunication facilities in the county. 
(b)  Assist the county in enforcement of this article. 
(c)  Assist the county in the collection and enforcement of any taxes, franchise fees, license fees or charges that may be due the county. 
(d)  Assist the county in monitoring compliance with local, state, and federal laws. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Secs. 90-124—90-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE 

Sec. 90-131. - Telecommunications license. 
A telecommunications license shall be required of any telecommunications carrier who desires to occupy specific public ways of the county for the sole purpose of providing telecommunications services to persons or areas outside the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-132. - License application. 
Any person who desires a telecommunications license pursuant to this division shall file an application with the county which shall include the following information: 
(a)  The identity of the license applicant, including all affiliates of the applicant. 
(b)  A description of the telecommunications services that are or will be offered or provided by the licensee over its telecommunications facilities. 
(c)  A description of the transmission medium that will be used by the licensee to offer or provide such telecommunications services. 
(d)  Preliminary engineering plans, specifications and a network map of the facilities to be located within the county, all in sufficient detail to identify: 
(1)  The location and route requested for applicant's proposed telecommunications facilities; 
(2)  The location of all overhead and underground public utility, telecommunication, cable, water, sewer drainage and other facilities in the public way along the proposed route; 
(3)  The location(s), if any, for interconnection with the telecommunications facilities of other telecommunications carriers; 
(4)  If a tower or tall structure, the distance in feet from the nearest tower or tall structure, whether or not owned by the applicant; 
(5)  The specific trees, structures, improvements, facilities and obstructions, if any, that applicant proposes to temporarily or permanently remove or relocate. 
(e)  If applicant is proposing to install overhead facilities, such facilities shall be installed on existing utility poles, towers or tall structures along the proposed route and shall furnish evidence that surplus space is available for locating its telecommunications facilities on existing utility poles, towers or tall structures along the proposed route; provided, however, that if use of existing structures would create an economic hardship or would not meet applicant's technical requirements, said applicant may request waiver of this requirement. Such request shall be part of the application, and shall be subject to review and approval or disapproval in the same manner as the full application. New towers shall be designed to accommodate at least three additional carriers of the same type of service for which the tower is being designed, unless applicant can show evidence that such accommodation would work undue economic hardship. 
(1)  If applicant is proposing to install a telecommunications tower or tall structure, evidence that space is not available for co-locating its telecommunications facilities on existing towers or tall structures within the county. 
(2)  Setback for said tower or tall structure would be the required setback for its zoning district, plus one foot for every two feet of height above the specified height limit for that district. 
(f)  If applicant is proposing an underground installation in existing ducts or conduits within the public ways, information in sufficient detail to identify: 
(1)  The excess capacity currently available in such ducts or conduits before installation of applicant's telecommunications facilities; 
(2)  The excess capacity, if any, that will exist in such ducts or conduits after installation of applicant's telecommunications facilities. 
(g)  If applicant is proposing an underground installation within new ducts or conduits to be constructed within the public ways: 
(1)  The location proposed for the new ducts or conduits; 
(2)  The excess capacity that will exist in such ducts or conduits after installation of applicant's telecommunications facilities. 
(h)  A preliminary construction schedule and completion date. 
(i)  A preliminary traffic control plan in accordance with the GDOT Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(j)  Financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles demonstrating the applicant's financial ability to construct, operate, maintain, relocate and remove the facilities. 
(k)  Information in sufficient detail to establish the applicant's technical qualifications, experience and expertise regarding the telecommunications facilities and services described in the application. 
(l)  Information to establish that the applicant has obtained all other governmental approvals and permits to construct and operate the facilities and to offer or provide the telecommunications services. 
(1)  Special exception for location within the county's zoning districts (zoning appeals board) Tift County. 
(2)  Construction permits (building department) as outlined in section 90-140 of this article and section 3-26 of the Tift County Zoning Ordinance. 
(3)  All federal or state permits required for specified telecommunications service. 
(m)  All fees, deposits or charges required pursuant to Division 6 of this article. 
(n)  Such other and further information as may be required by the county administrator. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-133. - Determination by the county. 
Within 90 calendar days after receiving a complete application under section 90-132 hereof, the governing authority shall issue a written determination granting or denying the application in whole or in part, applying the following standards. If the application is denied, the written determination shall include the reasons for denial. 
(a)  The financial and technical ability of the applicant. 
(b)  The legal ability of the applicant. 
(c)  The capacity of the public ways to accommodate the applicant's proposed facilities. 
(d)  The capacity of the public ways to accommodate additional utility and telecommunications facilities if the license is granted. 
(e)  The damage or disruption, if any, of public or private facilities, improvements, service, travel or landscaping if the license is granted. 
(f)  The public interest in minimizing the cost and disruption of construction within the public ways. 
(g)  The service that applicant will provide to the community and region. 
(h)  The effect, if any, on public health, safety and welfare if the license is granted. 
(i)  The availability of alternate routes and/or locations for the proposed facilities. 
(j)  Applicable federal and state telecommunications laws, regulations and policies. 
(k)  Such other factors as may demonstrate that the grant to use the public ways will serve the community interest. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-134. - Agreement. 
No license granted hereunder shall be effective until the applicant and the county have executed a written agreement setting forth the particular terms and provisions under which the license to occupy and use public ways of the county will be granted. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-135. - Nonexclusive grant. 
No license granted under this division shall confer any exclusive right, privilege, license or franchise to occupy or use the public ways of the county for delivery of telecommunications services or any other purposes. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-136. - Rights granted. 
No license granted under this division shall convey any right, title or interest in the public ways, but shall be deemed a license only to use and occupy the public ways for the limited purposes and term stated in the grant. Further, no license shall be construed as any warranty of title. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-137. - Term of grant. 
Unless otherwise specified in a license agreement, a telecommunications license granted hereunder shall be in effect for a term of five years. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-138. - License route. 
A telecommunications license granted under this division shall be limited to a grant of specific public ways and defined portions thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-139. - Location of facilities. 
Unless otherwise specified in a license agreement, all facilities shall be constructed, installed and located in accordance with the following terms and conditions: 
(a)  Telecommunications facilities shall be installed within an existing underground duct or conduit whenever excess capacity exists within such utility facility. 
(b)  A licensee with permission to install overhead facilities shall install its telecommunications facilities on pole attachments to existing utility poles, towers or tall structures only, pursuant to the requirements of section 90-132(e). 
(1)  If applicant is proposing to install a telecommunications tower or tall structure, evidence that space is not available for co-locating its telecommunications facilities on existing towers or tall structures within the county. 
(2)  Setback for said tower or tall structure would be the required setback to the zoning district, plus one foot for every two feet of height above the specified height limit for that district. 
(c)  Whenever any existing electric utilities, cable facilities or telecommunications facilities are located underground within a public way of the county, a licensee with permission to occupy the same public way must also locate its telecommunications facilities underground. 
(d)  Whenever any new or existing electric utilities, cable facilities or telecommunications facilities are located or relocated underground within a public way of the county, a grantee that currently occupies the same public way shall relocate its facilities underground within a reasonable period of time, which shall not be later than the end of the grant term. Absent extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship as determined by the county engineer, such relocation shall be made concurrently to minimize the disruption of the public ways. 
(e)  Whenever new telecommunications facilities will exhaust the capacity of a public street or utility easement to reasonably accommodate future telecommunications carriers or facilities, the grantee shall provide additional ducts, conduits, manholes and other facilities for nondiscriminatory access to future telecommunications carriers. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-140. - Construction permits. 
All licensees are required to obtain construction permits for telecommunications facilities as required in Division 7 of this article provided, however, that nothing in this division shall prohibit the county and a licensee from agreeing to alternative plan review, permit and construction procedures in a license agreement, provided such alternative procedures provide substantially equivalent safeguards for responsible construction practices. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-141. - Compensation to county. 
Each license granted under this division is subject to the county's right, which is expressly reserved, to annually fix a fair and reasonable compensation to be paid for the property rights granted to the licensee; provided, nothing in this division shall prohibit the county and a licensee from agreeing to the compensation to be paid. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-142. - Service to county users. 
A licensee may be permitted to offer or provide telecommunications services to persons or areas within the unincorporated areas of the county upon submitting an application for approval pursuant to Division 4 hereof. 
(Ord. of 8-11-97) 
Sec. 90-143. - Amendment of grant. 
(a)  A new license application and grant shall be required of any telecommunications carrier that desires to extend or locate its telecommunications facilities in public ways of the county which are not included in a license previously granted under this article.
