ARTICLE VI. - GROSS PREMIUMS TAX ON INSURERS OTHER THAN LIFE INSURER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. 

Sec. 102-146. - Levied. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, there is hereby levied for the year 1984, and for each year thereafter, an annual tax upon each insurer doing insurance business within the unincorporated area of the county, in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year on all insurance, other than life insurance, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(2), (3), (4) and (5). Gross direct premiums shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). 
(Res. of 9-12-83, § 1) 
Secs. 102-147—102-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— County hotel/motel occupancy tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 102-171. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chairman means the chairman of the board of commissioners. 
Clerk means the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
Due date means the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designated for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or portion of a structure, including a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp and tourist cabin, containing guestrooms and in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. As used in this article such word does not include any jail, hospital, orphanage, asylum, sanitarium or medical, mental, drug or alcohol treatment facility, or any governmental building. 
Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room, except when such room is being used as a meeting room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in the unincorporated areas of the county including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied any guestroom in a hotel for more than ten consecutive days next preceding such date. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state, and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-172. - Administration and enforcement of article. 
(a)  The chairman shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed under this article. 
(b)  Every operator shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the chairman may require from time to time. 
(c)  The chairman or any person authorized by him may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guest rooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. 
(d)  In administration of the provisions of this article, the chairman may require the filing of reports by any persons or class of persons having in such persons' possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax imposed under this article. The reports shall be filed with the chairman when required by the chairman and shall set forth the rents charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the chairman may from time to time require. 
(e)  The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this article, and all procedures for enforcement of such article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate's court by the chairman of the board of commissioners or a designated representative of the chairman and shall be prosecuted through that court. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, §§ 11, 15) 
Sec. 102-173. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person convicted of violating this article shall be subject to the imposition of punishment as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 14) 
Sec. 102-174. - Imposition and rate of tax. 
There shall be paid a tax of five percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guestroom in a hotel in the unincorporated areas of the county. The tax imposed by this article shall be paid upon any occupancy on or after May 1, 2000, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease or other arrangement made prior to such date. 
Two percent of the taxes collected shall be used for the purpose of promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows. Three percent of the taxes collected shall be used for improving lighting on Interstate 75, improvements at the Tifton-Tift County Airport and other public purposes pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1)(D)(9). 
The tax of two percent shall remain in effect through April 30, 2000. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 2; Ord. No. 2000-02, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 102-175. - Collection of tax by operator. 
Every operator maintaining a place of business in the unincorporated areas of the county, as provided in section 102-174, and renting guestrooms in the unincorporated areas of the county, not exempted under this article, shall collect a tax of five percent of the amount of the rent from the occupant. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 3; Ord. No. 2000-02, 3-13-00) 
Sec. 102-176. - Exemptions. 
(a)  No tax shall be levied under this article upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished to a permanent resident for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms. 
(b)  No tax shall be levied as provided in this article upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more consecutive days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 4) 
Sec. 102-177. - Registration of operator. 
(a)  Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in the unincorporated areas of the county shall immediately register with the county clerk on such form as shall be provided by the official. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of the place of business, and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the chairman may from time to time require. The registration shall be signed by the owner in the case of a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; and in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. 
(b)  The chairman of the board of commissioners shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from occupants. 
(c)  A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 5) 
Sec. 102-178. - Determination, returns and payments. 
(a)  All amounts of taxes due under this article shall be due and payable to the county monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. 
(b)  On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the clerk showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the clerk. 
(c)  Operators collecting the tax authorized by this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for, and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from the state sales and use tax under the state Retailer's and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act (1951 Ga. Laws, page 360; O.C.G.A. §§ 48-8-1—48-8-66). 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 6) 
Sec. 102-179. - Persons liable for tax. 
(a)  The taxes imposed pursuant to this article are imposed upon the operator and shall be collected by the operator from the occupant. The operator shall collect the tax imposed under this article from the occupant and shall pay the same over to the county as provided in this section. 
(b)  Each operator shall add the amount of the tax imposed under this article to the room rental charge, which shall be a debt from the occupant to the operator until paid, and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. Any operator who shall neglect, fail or refuse to collect the tax imposed pursuant to this article upon all rent due for occupancy, shall be personally liable for payment of the tax so imposed. 
(c)  No operator shall advertise or hold out to the public in any manner that such operator will absorb all or any portion of the tax imposed pursuant to this article or that such operator will relieve the occupant of the payment of all or any portion of the tax imposed pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Any operator liable for any tax imposed pursuant to this article who shall sell the hotel business of such operator, or shall quit the hotel business, shall make a final return and payment of all amounts due to the county pursuant to this article, all within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 7) 
Sec. 102-180. - Failure to pay tax. 
(a)  The tax imposed pursuant to this article shall for each month become delinquent on the 21st day of each succeeding month. The chairman shall, when any tax becomes delinquent under this article, pursue any remedy or right allowed by law for enforcement of the collection and payment of taxes imposed by the county as may be allowed under the laws of the state and the ordinances and resolutions of the county. 
(b)  Any operator who fails to pay the tax imposed pursuant to this article to the county or fails to pay to the county any amount of such tax required to be collected pursuant to this article within the time required for payment thereof shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax, or the amount of the tax not so paid within such time period, in addition to the tax or amount of tax not so paid within such time period, plus interest on the unpaid tax or portion thereof at a rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount or portion thereof should have been returned until date of payment. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 8) 
Sec. 102-181. - Deficiency determination. 
(a)  If the chairman is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required by this article to be paid to the county by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the due date of taxes. 
(c)  The chairman shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If made by mail, such service shall be made by certified mail and shall be addressed to the operator at the address of the operator as it appears in the records of the county. 
(d)  Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 9) 
Sec. 102-182. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  If any person fails to make a return, the chairman shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rents of such person within the unincorporated areas of the county which are subject to the tax required by this article. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon information which is or may come into the possession of the chairman. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 102-181(c). 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 10) 
Sec. 102-183. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
(a)  At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required by this article to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any such tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the chairman may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the county to collect amounts delinquent together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient sum from the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the chairman showing that the county has been paid in full or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price, as required under this article, such purchaser shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by such purchaser but only to the extent of the purchase price. 
(d)  Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the county under this article, it may be offset by the chairman. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the chairman, the operator will have three years from date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the chairman, the excess amount paid to the county may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators, representatives, successors or assigns. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 12) 
Sec. 102-184. - Retention of records. 
It shall be the duty of every operator required to make a report and pay any tax levied under this article to keep and preserve suitable records of rents taxable under this article, such other books of accounts and records as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax due under this article, and any other information as may be required by the chairman. It shall be the duty of every operator to keep and preserve for a period of three years all invoices and other records of occupancy and rents for occupancy which are taxable under this article with all such books, invoices, and other records to be open to examination by the chairman or any person authorized by him at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. of 6-1-89, § 13) 
Secs. 102-185—102-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SPECIAL STREET LIGHT TAX DISTRICTS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 102-201. - Authority for establishing special tax districts within the county. 
The Board of Commissioners of Tift County, Georgia, is authorized by Article 9, Section 2, Paragraph VI of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, to create special districts for the provision of local government services within such districts and to levy and collect fees, assessments and taxes within such districts to pay, wholly or partially, the cost of providing such services therein. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-202. - Declaration of policy and purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide the citizens of the county with a procedure for the installation, maintenance and operation of street lights in certain public rights-of-way in the unincorporated areas or the county. To that end, this article is adopted in order to effect the creation of street light tax districts to pay for services rendered by such street lights. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-203. - Definitions. 
(a)  Property owner. The term "property owner" or "owner," as used in this article, shall include all persons holding fee simple title according to the real estate records of Tift County within a proposed street light tax district at the time the petition for the creation of said district is submitted as provided herein. For the purpose of petitioning the board of commissioners for the creation of a new street light tax district, the property owner/owners shall have one vote per platted lot within a particular proposed street light tax district. The term "property owner" or "owner" specifically excludes tenants in possession of property within the street light tax district. 
(b)  Street light tax district. A "street light tax district" is a specific type of special tax district within the county. This type of special tax district is authorized pursuant to Article 9, Section 2, Paragraph VI of the Constitution of the State of Georgia. Street light tax districts may be created in order to collect the electricity charges incurred for street lights in said district. 
(c)  Existing subdivision. Any subdivision which has been approved by the county planning commission on or before the effective date of this article. 
(d)  New subdivision. Any subdivision which is approved by the planning commission after the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Secs. 102-204—102-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ESTABLISHMENT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 102-211. - Establishment of districts. 
(a)  Any property owner in any unincorporated area of the county may present a request for the creation of a street light district to the county administrator or his/her designee. The request shall designate boundaries for a street lighting district which shall serve the lot owner presenting the request and other property owners within said geographic area. The request shall include a plat or plats showing the proposed street lighting district. The office of the county administrator shall then provide a petition for the creation of the proposed street lighting district to be circulated by the presenter of the request among the lot owners in the proposed district. If the proposed street lighting district extends beyond the bounds of an existing subdivision and includes lots or parcels outside the existing subdivision, then not less than ten property owners representing not less than two-thirds of the property owners representing not less than two-thirds of the property within the existing subdivision, and not less than two-thirds of the property owners representing not less than two-thirds of the property outside the bounds of the existing subdivision must sign the petition in order to be presented to the board of commissioners. If the proposed street lighting district is completely within an existing subdivision, then not less than ten property owners representing not less than two-thirds of the property owners representing not less than two-thirds of the property must sign the petition for the creation of a street lighting district for the petition to be presented to the board of commissioners for consideration. A petition may be brought by less than ten property owners where such number represents 100 percent of the property owners within the district to be established. 
(b)  The petition for creation of the proposed street light district must be returned to the county administrator within 90 calendar days after it is obtained from the administrator's office. The county administrator or his designee shall verify the signatures on the petition and that the requisite number of property owners have signed said petition. 
(c)  By signing the petition for the creation of a new street lighting district, all petitioners within a proposed street light district shall be deemed to have actual or constructive notice of this article and all the provisions contained herein. In consideration of the street light services provided pursuant to this article, said petitioners shall agree to abide by and comply with all the provisions of this article. 
(d)  All successors-in-interest to the lot owners within a certain district at the time of creation of said street light tax district shall be deemed to have constructive notice of this article and the existing street light district wherein such lot is located due to the existence of public records containing such information. 
(e)  Upon receipt of a petition as provided herein and after a public hearing, the board of commissioners shall take under consideration the establishment of the requested special tax district. The board of commissioners, in its sole discretion, may vote to create one or more of such districts, but nothing contained herein shall be construed as creating an obligation on the board of commissioners to create any one or more of such districts. Likewise, nothing contained herein shall create any absolute right by any property owner or owners to the creation of any such district. The discretion as to whether to create any such district shall be that solely of the board of commissioners, based upon all the evidence available at the time of determination. Further, the creation by the board of commissioners of one or more such districts shall not create an absolute right by petitioners for another district or districts to the creation of such other district, nor shall the creation of one or more districts generate a precedent or obligation of the board of commissioners regarding the creation of additional special tax districts. The petition for each such special tax district shall be considered by the board of commissioners based upon the totality of the evidence regarding each respective proposed special tax district. The decision of the board of commissioners, in the exercise of its discretion, shall be final. 
(f)  The decision of the board of commissioners to create special street lighting district shall be evidenced by resolution adopted at a regular or special meeting of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-212. - Public hearing. 
After the names appearing on the petition are verified, an advertisement in the official legal publishing organ of the county shall run at least one time, not less than ten days prior to a public hearing on the petition. After the public hearing, the petition will be either approved or disapproved by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-213. - Street light construction by property developers for new subdivisions; constructive knowledge of street light districts created under this article. 
(a)  All developers of residential subdivisions, at the time of the submission of the preliminary plats or drawings of the development to the planning commission, may present a proposed street light service for the development and the establishment of a special street light tax district for the subdivision. The proposal presented by the developer must be approved by the planning commission prior to installation of street lights in the development. All fixtures and poles to be used shall be approved not only by the planning commission upon recommendation of the county engineer, but also by the utility company which will provide electricity to the street lights and which will be responsible for the maintenance of the facilities. Upon approval by the planning commission and receipt of written approval from the utility company, the board of commissioners may, upon petition, consider the creation of a special street light tax district for said subdivision. All rights and obligations shall be the same as set forth in section 102-211(e) hereinabove. 
(b)  The developer shall be billed by the county or utility provider for those charges contemplated in section 102-214(e) hereinbelow for the calendar year of creation of the special tax district and the calendar year thereafter. For subsequent years owners shall be billed their prorata share of said costs in the same manner as existing subdivisions which are designated as special tax districts. In addition, all purchasers of lots located in a new subdivision which has been designated as a special tax district as provided herein shall be deemed to have constructive notice or said district and the obligation imposed thereby due to the public records containing such information. 
(c)  All successors-in-interest to a developer in a subdivision wherein a street light district has been approved under this section shall have constructive notice of said district due to the existence of public records containing such information. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-214. - Pre-payment for services. 
Upon submission of the petition as contemplated by section 102-211 hereinabove, or request for consideration after planning commission approval as contemplated by section 102-213 above, there shall be delivered to the board of commissioners by the party or parties seeking tax district creation under this chapter, sufficient certified funds to pay for the estimated total costs, including administration fees, of providing the services for the special street lighting tax district from the time of inception of said tax district until the end of the calendar year in which the tax district is created, said sum to be deposited by the county and drawn upon to pay the expenses of street light services until the ad valorem tax bills for the year in which the tax district is created are due, which said tax bills shall include the charges to the respective property owners for the next calendar year as hereinafter provided. The total estimated cost, including administrative costs, for the calendar year following the year of creation, shall be billed on the ad valorem tax notices due on December 20 of the year of creation and likewise for each year thereafter. 
(a)  Total costs shall include the cost of the street lights and poles, the cost of installing the street lights, any costs for the subsequent maintenance of said street lights, and estimated cost of electricity for street light services. 
(1)  Initial costs of street lights and poles and the cost of installing the street lights may be prorated over a period of seven years, with prior approval of the board of commissioners. If initial costs are prorated, interest will be added to the cost at the rate of five percent per year from the inception of said tax district until all initial costs, including interest, are paid in full. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-215. - Approved street light tax districts. 
Each approved street light tax district shall be assigned a number and shall be designated by recorded plats showing each lot therein. 
(a)  A register of street light tax districts shall be maintained in the office of the board of commissioners and the office of the county tax commissioner. Such registers shall be available to the public for inspection upon reasonable notice to either of these offices. 
(b)  The cost of the street lights and poles, the cost of installing the street lights, and any costs for the subsequent maintenance of said street lights shall be the responsibility of the developer, the property owners, the utility company contracting to provide electrical services for the street lights in that district, or such other entities having an interest in such service. The county shall not be responsible for any such costs. 
(c)  The cost of electricity for street light services as provided by this article shall be the responsibility of the owners of the property within the special tax district. The prorata cost of the electricity shall be assigned to each platted lot within the special tax district. 
(d)  Administrative costs incurred by the county in the collection of the street light tax shall be the responsibility of the property owners in the district for which said costs were incurred. This administrative charge assessed each year shall be set by the board of commissioners, but shall not exceed 15 percent of the total charges of the utility company for that district for the preceding year; provided, however, that the maximum administrative charge provided herein may be decreased or increased from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners. Provided further, that the board of commissioners shall be authorized to establish different administrative charges for different special tax districts and to adjust the respective rates from time to time by resolution, after taking into consideration all of the cost factors involved in collecting the charges contemplated by this article, including, but not limited to, the delinquency rate within a particular special tax district. The prorata portion of administrative charges for each lot shall be charged to the owners of the property. Notwithstanding anything herein, the minimum annual administrative fee for any special street light tax district shall be $50.00. 
(e)  The total charge to property owners for street lighting services shall be on a per lot basis as determined by resolution of the board of commissioners, giving consideration for the electrical service charges from the utility company for street light services within the district, the administrative costs incurred by the county in the collection of the street light tax, and the number of lots irrespective of the size or improvements on such lots. The rates charged shall in no case be less than that charged to the county for said street lights. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-216. - Collection and responsibility for administration. 
(a)  The charges for street lighting in each street lighting district shall be paid as a street light district tax, and shall be collected concurrently with the ad valorem tax billed to each lot owner within each street light tax district. The date for determining ownership of each lot shall be January 1 of each year. 
(b)  The administration, payment and accounting of the services herein authorized shall be the responsibility of the board of commissioners or some department of the county government to which that responsibility shall be assigned by the board of commissioners. Any proration of such charges between owners of lots to which title is transferred during any year shall be the responsibility of the sellers and buyers of said lots. 
(c)  The office of the tax commissioner of the county shall be responsible for the timely collection of the taxes, fees and assessments assessed to each street light tax district and shall remit said sums to the board of commissioners in the same manner as other taxes are remitted. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-217. - Charges and imposition of liens. 
In addition to any other rights or collection for late or unpaid charges, the county shall have all rights available under the laws of the state for assessment, the creation of a lien upon the property of the owner receiving the service provided, together with all rights of execution, levy, foreclosure and sale. Such lien shall have the same priority as tax assessments. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-218. - Authority to contract with public utilities. 
The board of commissioners may contract with the public utilities for the purpose of carrying out the terms of this article. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-219. - Termination/elimination of street light tax district by county; by lot owners within district. 
(a)  Termination by county. The board of commissioners may terminate or abolish any and all street light tax districts within the county by resolution. Any such termination or abolition shall be effective January 1 of the year following the adoption of said resolution. Upon said termination, the county shall not be responsible for the collection of fees, assessments, and taxes for electrical services rendered for street lights after the date of termination, and shall not be responsible for the charges of the utility company for electricity for said street lights after termination. 
(b)  Termination by lot owners within the district. At any time, the property owners within a street light district may request the board of commissioners to terminate said district by submission of a petition containing the signatures of the owners of two-thirds of the lots within the district. Based upon all available information, the board of commissioners shall be authorized but not required to grant the property owners' request to terminate the street light tax district. Any such termination shall be effective January 1 of the year following the adoption by the board of commissioners of the termination resolution. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-220. - Federal, state laws to prevail in conflicts. 
If any provision of this article is in conflict with any state or federal law, or with any rule, regulation or order of any agency of this state or federal agency having jurisdiction of the subject matter of this article, it is hereby deemed to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the state or federal law or rule, regulation or order, as the case may be, shall prevail so that the remaining portion of this article shall be deemed to be of full force and effect. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Secs. 102-221—102-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 102-231. - Adoption. 
(a)  The American Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting, as sponsored by the Illuminating Engineering Society and approved by the American Standards Association on July 11, 1973, as amended and currently exists, is hereby adopted as the standard for installation and operation of street and roadway lighting in the unincorporated areas of the county. A copy of these standards is on file with the county engineer and in the oflice of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Lighting fixtures installed within the public riglits-of-way to be operated for the purpose of street illumination shall comply with these standards. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-232. - Approval of proposed installations; appeal from disapproval; manner of installation. 
(a)  Any party requesting permission to install or operate lighting fixtures within public rights-of-way shall furnish plans and specifications to the county engineer for approval showing how the proposed lighting meets the standards, and no lighting shall be installed or operated without such approval. Should the county engineer disapprove the request to install or operate lighting fixtures within any public right-of-way because of the failure to meet standards, he/she shall communicate such disapproval in writing to the party requesting same. Such written communication shall include the specific reasons for disapproval. Any disapproval of a light or lighting system by the county engineer may be appealed to the board of commissioners. If any party desires to appeal an adverse decision by the county engineer, a notice of appeal shall be filed with the county engineer within 30 days from the date following the written notice of disapproval, and it shall be the responsibility of the county engineer to transmit forthwith to the board of commissioners all papers and allied documents constituting the record upon which the action appealed was taken from and to insure that such appeal is promptly placed upon the agenda of the board for its determination. The board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from. 
(b)  Roadway or street lighting luminaries or fixtures installed within the public rights-of- way as "security lights," or for the purpose of lighting areas other than the public streets, shall be mounted on the side of the pole opposite from such street and shall be oriented in such a manner to insure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street, so as to protect the users of the street from objectionable glare. The approval of the county engineer shall be obtained before installation of such lights. 
(c)  Other lighting fixtures to be installed within or outside or public rights-of-way for whatever purpose shall be installed and operated in such a manner as to prevent glare from being a hazard to or interfering with the normal use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Sec. 102-233. - Installation and operation. 
The installation and operation of lighting fixtures located within the rights-of-way of any public street, road, highway, sidewalk or alley in the unincorporated areas or the county, or affixed to any pole, lamp post, standard or other supporting device which is located within such rights-of-way, shall follow the following procedures: 
(a)  Plans and specifications for the proposed installation showing compliance with these standards will be submitted to the county engineer for approval. No installations shall be made without this approval. 
(b)  Fixtures for illuminating areas adjoining the public streets, roads, etc., such as parking areas, driveways, etc., will be mounted in such a manner as to insure that the light pattern is kept off the public highway. When street or roadway lighting luminaries are to be used for "security lighting," they will be mounted on the side of the pole that is opposite from the public street and will be mounted to insure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street and the vertical light distribution at the initial light source is perpendicular to the street. 
(c)  If lighting fixtures of a type other than those in the classification of street or roadway luminaries are to be used or if the proposed lighting is to be for other than drives, parking areas or other similar area lighting, the plans and specifications submitted shall be sufficiently detailed to clearly show that such a proposal is in compliance with these standards and will not cause a hazard to, or interfere with, the normal use of the public streets, roads or highways. 
(Ord. of 10-13-97) 
Secs. 102-234—102-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - EXCISE TAX ON THE SALE, USE, STORAGE OR CONSUMPTION OF ENERGY 

Sec. 102-241. - Energy excise tax definitions. 
As used in this article, the terms: "dealer;" "energy;" "local sales and use tax;" and "purchaser" shall have the same meanings as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 1, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 102-242. - Imposition; rate; remitting; recovery; liabilities. 
In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110 et seq., there is imposed within the territorial limits of the special district created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-111, an excise tax on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy when such sale, use, storage, or consumption would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 2, 2-11-13) 
State Law reference— The excise tax is tied to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. There is no authorization under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110 et seq. to levy this tax on bona fide energy used in agriculture. Please review carefully the definitions and scope of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-8-3.2 & 48-8-3.3 to determine the proper scope of the agricultural provisions. 
Sec. 102-243. - Excise tax rate; phase-in. 
(a)  Such excise tax shall be levied and collected by the governing authority of the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112 and 48-13-114 and as provided in this section. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, the rate of such excise tax shall be phased in over a four-year period as follows: 
(1)  For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 25 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(2)  For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 50 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(3)  For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 75 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and 
(4)  On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(c)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2 (c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of subsection (b) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in paragraph (4) of subsection (b) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016 limitation in that paragraph (4). 
(d)  (1)  Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the county shall be directed by O.C.G.A, § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two percent (except in the case where the municipal option water and sewer tax is levied where that rate will be three percent. See state law reference below.). 
(2)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district decreases from two percent to one percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. 
(3)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district increases from one percent to two percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 3, 2-11-13) 
State Law reference— Under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(a)(3), if the tax is imposed before January 1, 2016, the rate will gradually phase in as the rate of local sales and use tax phases out. Under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114, after the actual rate imposed follows the rate of local sales and use tax (defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110(3). It will be either one percent or two percent, with the exception of a city which levies municipal option water and sewer tax, in which case the rate would be three percent. 
Sec. 102-244. - Imposition; remittance; recovery. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c), such excise tax shall be: 
(1)  Imposed only at the time sales and use tax on the sale or use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 but for the exemption under O.C.G.A. §48-8-3.2; 
(2)  Due and payable in the same manner as would be required under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq., except as other provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq.; 
(3)  A debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts; 
(4)  Remitted to the governing authority of the county by the dealer collecting such excise tax; and 
(5)  A liability of the dealer at the applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of excise taxes collected from purchasers, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 4, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 102-245. - Exemption certificates. 
(a)  The governing authority of the county, or the collecting officer appointed under section 102-248 of this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the special district and to ascertain whether such a purchaser has completed a uniform exemption certificate provided from the website of the state department of revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser for the exemption under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this chapter. 
(b)  An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates. An energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed pursuant to this chapter if the purchaser has failed to submit such uniform exemption certificate to the energy provider. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 5, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 102-246. - Commencement of collections. 
The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective on February 11, 2013, and shall be due and payable to the governing authority of the county monthly on or before the twentieth day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 6, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 102-247. - Distribution and expenditure of proceeds. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114, the excise tax proceeds shall be paid into the general fund of Tift County and shall not be subject to any use or expenditure requirements provided for under any of the local sales and use taxes but shall be authorized to be expended in the same manner as otherwise would have been required under such local sales and use taxes or may be expended for any lawful purpose as determined by the governing authority of Tift County. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 7, 2-11-13) 
Sec. 102-248. - Administrative provisions; audits; examinations; collecting officer. 
(a)  The governing authority of the county shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer (The collecting officer could be any appropriate person as determined by the governing authority. The tax commissioner could be designated if the tax commissioner consents to the designation) for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)  The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. The collecting officer, or the designee of the collecting officer, is specifically authorized to examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, or other facilities of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax under this article. 
(c)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-118, as part of the audit report required under O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-01, § 8, 2-11-13) 
Chapter 106 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; roads and bridges, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Deposit of driver's license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; authority of county to regulate traffic in unincorporated areas, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.; traffic offenses triable on complaint without indictment except in superior courts, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-3; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 106-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-2—40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the county with like effect as if recited in this section. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by state law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-11. 
State Law reference— Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372. 
Sec. 106-2. - Use of speed detection devices. 
The board of commissioners of the county desires and approves the use of speed detection devices by its law enforcement officers. 
(Res. of 1-4-88) 
Sec. 106-3. - Interference with traffic control or railroad sign or device. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control sign or traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon or any other part thereof. 
(b)  Ignoring such signs. No person shall, without lawful authority, drive around or through or ignore any official traffic control device or sign so as to go onto an officially closed highway or road or onto a section of highway or road before it has been officially opened to the public. This subsection shall not apply to law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties, to individuals domiciled or making their livelihood within the affected area or to any person authorized to be in the affected area by the appropriate county or state officer. 
(c)  Enforcement. The sheriff of the county and his designated deputies and the county administrator or his designee shall have authority to conduct such investigation as deemed necessary for the enforcement of this section. All formal charges brought under this section shall be initiated by citation and heard before the magistrate court of the county. 
(d)  Violation and remedies. Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be deemed to be in violation herewith and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11. The judge may in his sole discretion suspend, stay or probate any type of punishment imposed under this subsection. 
(Ord. of 9-11-95, §§ 2—4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-26. 
Sec. 106-4. - Abandoned motor vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to abandon any motor vehicle as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 40, Chapter 11. Any motor vehicle abandoned within the county shall be disposed of by the proper authorities as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 40, Chapter 11. 
(Mo. of 5-13-96) 
Secs. 106-5—106-30. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-56. - Stopping, standing and parking; prohibited areas. 
The stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is prohibited within the limits of the following described locations: 
(1)  State Route 7, US 41, both sides from Peachtree Street (County Road 274), M.L. 7.68, northward to Hill Avenue (County Road 275), M.L. 7.88, a distance of 1,056 feet. 
(2)  The roadway or shoulders next to the north or south sides of Whiddon Mill Road (County Road No. 412) between the west city limits line of the City of Tifton, Georgia, and the entrance to the Agrirama. 
(3)  South Central Avenue from the city limits of Tifton to I-75. 
(4)  The north and south side of U.S. 82 from the city limits of Tifton to the Little River Bridge. 
(5)  The roadway or emergency lanes next to the north or south curbs of State Highway No. 50 (U.S. 82) between the west city limits line of the City of Tifton, Georgia, and the east entrance to the Little River Bridge. 
(Res. of 1-9-78; Mo. of 7-7-80; Mo. of 4-5-82; Ord. of 9- -94) 
Secs. 106-57—106-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COUNTY ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING 

Sec. 106-76. - Applicability of division. 
This division shall be applicable to all parking spaces and parking lots located between Tift Avenue and Chesnutt Avenue on property owned by Tift County, Georgia, adjacent to the county administrative building and to the parking lot located on the north side of Library Lane and the west side of Tift Avenue. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(2), § 1) 
Sec. 106-77. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Parking space means any space marked with traffic paint and designated for parking of a vehicle. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(2), § 2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-78. - Regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division to park longer than 30 minutes in any parking spaces and any open area in the parking lot immediately west of the county administrative building. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division to park in any parking space designated for the handicapped unless the car so parking has attached thereto a valid handicapped decal. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division to park anywhere except in a marked parking space in the parking areas north and east of the county administrative building and in the parking lot north of Library Lane and west of Tift Avenue. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(2), § 3) 
Sec. 106-79. - Enforcement of division. 
The county magistrate's court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this division, and all procedures for enforcement of such division shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violations of any provision of this division shall be brought before the magistrate's court by the county sheriff, any deputy county sheriff, the chairman of the board of commissioners or a designated representative of the chairman of the board of commissioners and shall be prosecuted through that court. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(2), § 5) 
Sec. 106-80. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person convicted of violating this division shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed $50.00. 
(Ord. of 4-4-88(2), § 4) 
Secs. 106-81—106-100. - Reserved.
